43.2

In section 248E of TCGA 1992 (relief on disposal of joint interests in private
residence), at end insert—

43.2.9

This section applies in relation to cases where, immediately before the
disposal, the land is held by a partnership comprising the landowner and the
co-owner or co-owners (whether the partnership is formed in Scotland or
elsewhere) as it applies in relation to other cases (and the partners are
regarded as the landowner and the co-owner or co-owners for the purposes of
this section).

43.3

The amendments made by  this section  have effect in relation to disposals
made on or after 6 April 2023.

### Alcohol Duty

#### Charge to alcohol duty

##### Alcoholic products

###### Meaning of “alcoholic product”

44

44.1

In  this Part , “ alcoholic product ” means any of the following—

44.1.a

spirits,

44.1.b

beer,

44.1.c

cider,

44.1.d

wine, and

44.1.e

any other fermented product.

44.2

But a product listed in  subsection (1)  is not an alcoholic product if it is
of an alcoholic strength of 1.2% or less.

44.3

Schedule 6  defines each category of alcoholic product (and makes further
provision in connection with the definitions).

###### Alcoholic strength

45

45.1

The “alcoholic strength” of an alcoholic product is the ratio, expressed as a
percentage, of—

45.1.a

the volume of the alcohol contained in the product, to

45.1.b

the volume of the product (inclusive of the alcohol contained in it).

45.2

The alcoholic strength of any alcoholic product is to be determined by
reference to the product as at 20°C.

45.3

The Commissioners may by regulations make provision about the means of
ascertaining the alcoholic strength, weight or volume of any alcoholic product
or other substance (including products or substances that are not in liquid
form at 20°C) for the purposes of  this Part .

45.4

Regulations under  subsection (3)  may, in particular, include provision for
ascertaining the alcoholic strength, weight or volume of anything contained in
a bottle or container by reference to information given on the bottle or
container or in documents relating to it.

45.5

In  this Part , “ alcohol ” means ethanol.

###### Categories of alcoholic products: regulations

46

The Treasury may by regulations—

46.a

amend  Schedule 6 ;

46.b

provide that a beverage of an alcoholic strength exceeding 1.2%, of a
description specified by or under the regulations, is to be treated as being
an alcoholic product of a particular category listed in  section 44  (whether
or not it would otherwise fall within another category listed in that
section).

##### Charge and rates

###### Alcohol duty: charge

47

47.1

An excise duty (“alcohol duty”) is charged on alcoholic products that are
produced in, or imported into, the United Kingdom.

47.2

But  subsection (1)  is subject to the exemptions in  Chapters 4  and  6 .

###### Rates

48

48.1

Alcohol duty is charged at the rates shown in  Schedule 7 .

48.2

But  subsection (1)  is subject to—

48.2.a

section 50  (draught relief), and

48.2.b

section 54  (small producer relief).

###### Excise duty point and payment

49

49.1

Alcohol duty is to be paid, and the amount chargeable is to be determined and
become due, in accordance with provision made by or under—

49.1.a

section 88 ;

49.1.b

section 1 of F(No. 2)A 1992.

49.2

In  this Part , “ excise duty point ” has the meaning given by section 1 of
F(No. 2)A 1992.

#### Draught relief

##### Qualifying draught products: reduced rates

50

50.1

Alcohol duty is charged on qualifying draught products at the reduced rates
shown in  Schedule 8  (instead of at the rates shown in  Schedule 7  (the
“full rates”)).

50.2

But a person liable to pay alcohol duty on qualifying draught products may,
for the purposes of  section 52 (2) , elect for duty to be charged at the full
rates.

##### Alcoholic products qualifying for draught relief

51

51.1

“ Qualifying draught products ” means alcoholic products that—

51.1.a

are of an alcoholic strength of less than 8.5%, and

51.1.b

at the excise duty point are contained in, or are being transported to a place
in the United Kingdom for the purpose of being transferred to, a large draught
container.

51.2

But alcoholic products that are produced in the United Kingdom by a person
otherwise than in accordance with an approval under  section 82  are not
qualifying draught products.

51.3

A “ large draught container ” means a container which—

51.3.a

is of a capacity of at least 20 litres, and

51.3.b

incorporates, or is designed to connect to, a qualifying system for dispensing
individual drinks.

51.4

For the purposes of  subsection (3) (b) , “ qualifying system ” means—

51.4.a

a pressurised gas delivery system, or

51.4.b

a pump delivery system.

51.5

The Commissioners may by regulations—

51.5.a

amend  subsection (3) (a)  so as to specify a different capacity;

51.5.b

amend  subsection (4)  so as to add or remove, or to vary the description of,
a qualifying system.

##### Repackaging qualifying draught products

52

52.1

For the purposes of  this section , qualifying draught products are
“repackaged” if—

52.1.a

they are transferred to containers that are not large draught containers, but

52.1.b

are not transferred in the course of serving a beverage for immediate
consumption.

52.2

A person may not repackage qualifying draught products on any premises in the
United Kingdom unless—

52.2.a

the repackaging is authorised, or

52.2.b

alcohol duty was charged on the products at the full rates, in accordance with
an election under  section 50 (2) .

52.3

Repackaging is “authorised” if it is carried out by a person who is—

52.3.a

approved and registered under section 100G of CEMA 1979 by virtue of
regulation 3 of the Warehousekeepers and Owners of Warehoused Goods
Regulations 1999 ( S.I. 1999/1278 ), or

52.3.b

approved under  section 82  (producers of alcoholic products).

52.4

Where the repackaging of qualifying draught products is authorised, an amount
equal to the duty shortfall is treated, for the purposes of  this Part , as an
amount of alcohol duty charged on the repackaged products.

52.5

In  this section  and in  section 53 , the “ duty shortfall ” in relation to
repackaged qualifying draught products is the difference between—

52.5.a

the alcohol duty payable on the alcoholic products under  section 50 (1)
(draught products: reduced rates), and

52.5.b

the alcohol duty that would have been payable on the alcoholic products under
section 48  (rates) if they had not, at the excise duty point, been qualifying
draught products.

52.6

For the purposes of subsection (2), the Commissioners may by regulations
require a person to provide, on the supply to another person of qualifying
draught products in respect of which an election under  section 50 (2)  has
been made, information or documents, of a description specified by or under
the regulations, as evidence that duty has been charged at the full rates.

##### Repackaging in contravention of 

53

53.1

This section  applies if a person repackages qualifying draught products in
contravention of  section 52 (2) .

53.2

The Commissioners may—

53.2.a

assess as alcohol duty due from the person mentioned in  subsection (1)  an
amount equal to the duty shortfall, and

53.2.b

notify that person or that person’s representative of any assessment under
paragraph (a) .

53.3

The conduct mentioned in  subsection (1)  attracts a penalty under section 9
of FA 1994, calculated by reference to the amount of duty referred to in
section 52 (5) (b) .

53.4

Any alcoholic products, articles (including packaging or equipment) or
substances in the person's possession, used (or which may be used) for or in
connection with the repackaging, are liable to forfeiture.

#### Small producer relief

##### Main provisions

###### Small producer relief: discounted rates

54

54.1

Alcohol duty is charged at the discounted rate on small producer alcoholic
products produced in a particular production year (the “current year”).

54.2

The discounted rate, in relation to small producer alcoholic products, is
equal to—

54.2.a

the standard rate, less

54.2.b

the duty discount for those products (determined in accordance with  section
59  and  Schedule 9 ).

54.3

In  subsection (2) (a) , the “ standard rate ”, in relation to alcoholic
products, means—

54.3.a

the rate shown for products of that kind in  Schedule 7 , or

54.3.b

if  Schedule 8  applies (and no election has been made under  section 50 (2) )
in relation to the products) the rate shown for products of that kind in that
Schedule.

54.4

For the purposes of this Chapter—

54.4.a

a “production year” is a period of 12 months beginning with 1 February;

54.4.b

the “ previous year ”, in relation to alcoholic products, is the production
year immediately preceding the current year in relation to those products.

###### Small producer alcoholic products

55

55.1

“Small producer alcoholic products” are alcoholic products that—

55.1.a

are of an alcoholic strength of less than 8.5%,

55.1.b

are produced on premises that are small production premises,

55.1.c

are not produced under licence, and

55.1.d

meet such other conditions (if any) as are specified by regulations made by
the Commissioners.

55.2

Subsection (1)  is subject to  section 58  (exclusions).

###### Small production premises

56

56.1

Production premises are “small production premises” in the current year in
relation to alcoholic products if—

56.1.a

the production limit condition is met, and

56.1.b

the unlicensed product condition is met.

56.2

The “production limit condition” is met in relation to non-group premises if,
in relation to those premises, neither of the following amounts exceeds the
small production limit—

56.2.a

the alcohol production amount for the previous year;

56.2.b

the estimated alcohol production amount for the current year,

56.3

The “production limit condition” is met in relation to group premises if
neither of the following amounts exceeds the small production limit—

56.3.a

the aggregate of the alcohol production amount, in relation to every set of
premises in the production group, for the previous year;

56.3.b

the aggregate of the estimated alcohol production amount, in relation to every
set of premises in the production group, for the current year.

56.4

The “small production limit” is 4500 hectolitres.

56.5

The “unlicensed product condition” is met—

56.5.a

in relation to non-group premises if the condition in  subsection (6)  is met
in relation to those premises;

56.5.b

in relation to group premises if the condition in  subsection (6)  is met in
relation to every set of premises in the production group.

56.6

The condition is that—

56.6.a

less than half of the alcohol production amount (if any), in relation to the
premises, for the previous year was contained in alcoholic products produced
under licence, and

56.6.b

the producer reasonably estimates that less than half of the alcohol
production amount, in relation to the premises, for the current year will be
contained in alcoholic products produced under licence.

###### “Alcohol production amount” etc

57

57.1

In relation to production premises—

57.1.a

the “alcohol production amount” for a production year is the total amount of
alcohol contained in alcoholic products produced on those premises in that
year, and

57.1.b

the “estimated alcohol production amount” for a production year is the
producer’s reasonable estimate of the alcohol production amount for those
premises in that year.

57.2

Subsection (1)  is subject to  subsections (3)  to  (6) .

57.3

The reference in  subsection (1)  to the alcoholic products produced on a set
of premises does not include a reference to any alcoholic products that are—

57.3.a

spoilt or destroyed before the excise duty point, or

57.3.b

produced in the course of producing a different alcoholic product on those
premises or on any set of connected premises.

57.4

Subsection (5)  applies where premises are in use for the purposes of the
production of alcoholic products for part only (the “relevant part”) of a
production year (including where premises begin to be used for those purposes
part-way through a production year).

57.5

The alcohol production amount or (as the case may be) the estimated alcohol
production amount is treated, for the purposes of  this Part , as being the
amount given by—

57.5.a

dividing the actual alcohol production amount, or (as the case may be) the
estimate of that amount, by the number of days in the relevant part of the
production year, and

57.5.b

multiplying the amount given by  paragraph (a)  by the number of days in the
production year.

57.6

The Commissioners may, if satisfied that the circumstances are exceptional,
agree with a producer that certain alcoholic products, or a certain quantity
of alcoholic products, may be disregarded for the purposes of determining—

57.6.a

the alcohol production amount, or

57.6.b

the estimated alcohol production amount,

in relation to production premises for any production year.

###### Exclusions

58

Alcoholic products produced on any premises are not “small producer alcoholic
products” if—

58.a

they are exempt from duty under any of  sections 72 ,  76  or  77 ,

58.b

they are produced in the United Kingdom by a person otherwise than in
accordance with an approval under  section 82 ,

58.c

at the time they are produced, the alcohol production amount attributable to
the premises (in the case of non-group premises) or the production group (in
the case of group premises) for the current year has exceeded the small
production limit, or

58.d

they are produced—

58.d.i

in the case of non-group premises, before the producer has estimated (for the
purposes of  section 57 ) the alcohol production amount attributable to the
premises for the current year, or

58.d.ii

in the case of group premises, before the producer in relation to those
premises or any connected premises has estimated (for the purposes of  section
57 ) the alcohol production amount attributable to those premises or any
connected premises for that year.

###### Duty discount for small producer alcoholic products

59

59.1

The duty discount, in relation to small producer alcoholic products in a
discount band, is the amount (in £ per litre of alcohol) given by the formula
in subsection (2) and rounded up to the nearest penny.

59.2

The formula is—

C + ( M ( A - S ) ) A where— C is the cumulative discount for the discount
band (in £); M is the marginal discount for the discount band (in £); A is the
relevant production amount (in hectolitres); S is the start threshold for the
discount band (in hectolitres).

59.3

Where the alcoholic products are produced on non-group premises, the “relevant
production amount” is—

59.3.a

the alcohol production amount, in relation to those premises, for the previous
year, or

59.3.b

if that amount would be nil, the estimated alcohol production amount in
relation to those premises for the current year.

59.4

Where the alcoholic products are produced on group premises, the “relevant
production amount” is —

59.4.a

the aggregate of the alcohol production amount for the previous year, in
relation to every set of premises in the production group on which alcoholic
products were produced in that year, or

59.4.b

if there are no premises in the production group on which alcoholic products
were produced in the previous year, the aggregate of the estimated alcoholic
production amount, in relation to every set of premises in the production
group, for the current year.

59.5

Small producer alcoholic products are in a particular discount band if the
relevant production amount in relation to those products—

59.5.a

exceeds the start threshold for that band, but

59.5.b

does not exceed the end threshold for that band.

59.6

The start and end thresholds, cumulative discount and marginal discount for a
discount band are the figures shown—

59.6.a

in relation to alcoholic products (other than qualifying draught products
referred to in paragraph (b)) of a particular description, in the tables in
Part 1 of  Schedule 9 , and

59.6.b

in relation to qualifying draught products (in respect of which no election
has been made under section 50(2)) of a particular description, in the tables
in Part 2 of  Schedule 9 .

###### Assessments where incorrectly low rate of alcohol duty applied

60

60.1

This section  applies if—

60.1.a

alcohol duty is charged on alcoholic products,

60.1.b

it appears at the excise duty point that the alcoholic products are small
producer alcoholic products, and

60.1.c

it turns out that the alcoholic products were not small producer alcoholic
products (including where circumstances were not as they appeared at the
excise duty point or where circumstances subsequently changed).

60.2

This section  also applies if—

60.2.a

alcohol duty is charged on small producer alcoholic products, and

60.2.b

the discounted rate that at the excise duty point appeared to be the correct
rate turns out to be lower than the correct rate (including where
circumstances were not as they appeared at the excise duty point or where
circumstances subsequently changed).

60.3

The Commissioners—

60.3.a

may assess as being alcohol duty due from the liable person an amount equal to
the duty shortfall, and

60.3.b

must notify that person or that person’s representative of any assessment
under  paragraph (a) .

60.4

In  this section  “ duty shortfall ” means the difference between—

60.4.a

the actual amount of alcohol duty chargeable on the alcoholic products, and

60.4.b

the lower amount that, at the excise duty point, appeared to be the amount
chargeable.

60.5

The reference in  subsection (3)  to the “ liable person ” is a reference to
the person liable to pay the alcohol duty on the alcoholic products.

##### Mergers and demergers

###### Mergers: general provisions

61

61.1

This section  and  sections 62  to  67  apply where a small producer (“SP1”)
becomes connected with another small producer ( “SP2” ).

61.2

“ Post-merger production group ” means the production group that consists of—

61.2.a

every set of premises on which SP1 or SP2 produces alcoholic products, and

61.2.b

every set of connected premises,

and references to “post-merger production group premises” are to premises
within  paragraph (a)  or  (b) .

61.3

In relation to the post-merger production group—

61.3.a

“ Year 1 ” means the production year in which SP1 and SP2 become connected
with one another,

61.3.b

“ Year 2 ” means the production year immediately following Year 1,

61.3.c

“ Year 3 ” means the production year immediately following Year 2, and

61.3.d

the “ pre-merger year ” means the production year immediately preceding Year
1.

61.4

Each of Year 1, Year 2 and Year 3 is a “ merger transition year ” in relation
to the post-merger production group, unless any of the following apply—

61.4.a

section 65  (early termination of merger transition period),

61.4.b

section 66  (subsequent mergers), or

61.4.c

section 68 (8)  (demergers in a merger transition year).

###### Modified “small production premises” test

62

62.1

This section  (instead of  section 56 ) applies in relation to a post-merger
production group in a merger transition year.

62.2

Post-merger production group premises are “small production premises” in the
current year in relation to alcoholic products if—

62.2.a

the adjusted post-merger amount, determined in accordance with  section 64
does not exceed the small production limit (within the meaning of  section 56
(4) ), and

62.2.b

in relation to each set of post-merger production group premises, less than
half of the alcohol production amount (if any), in relation to those premises,
for the previous year was contained in alcoholic products produced under
licence.

###### Modified duty discount

63

63.1

This section  applies in relation to alcoholic products that are produced—

63.1.a

on post-merger production group premises, and

63.1.b

in a merger transition year.

63.2

For the purposes of  section 59 , references to the “ relevant production
amount ” are references to the adjusted post-merger amount (and subsections
(3) and (4) of that section do not apply).

63.3

Section 58 (c)  does not apply for the purposes of the application of  section
55  or  59  in a merger transition year.

###### Adjusted post-merger amount

64

64.1

In Year 1, the adjusted post-merger amount is the alcohol production amount in
relation to the larger producer’s premises for the pre-merger year, determined
in accordance with  section 57  (and the alcohol production amount
attributable to the smaller producer for the pre-merger year is disregarded).

64.2

In Year 2, the adjusted post-merger amount is the total of—

64.2.a

the adjusted post-merger amount in Year 1, and

64.2.b

one-third of the production difference for Year 2.

64.3

In Year 3, the adjusted post-merger amount is the total of—

64.3.a

the adjusted post-merger amount in Year 1, and

64.3.b

two-thirds of the production difference for Year 3.

64.4

The amount of the “production difference” for a merger transition year is the
difference between—

64.4.a

the aggregate of the alcohol production amount, in relation to every set of
post-merger production group premises, for the previous year (determined in
accordance with  section 57 ), and

64.4.b

the adjusted post-merger amount in Year 1.

64.5

If the alcohol production amount attributable to SP1’s premises for the pre-
merger year is greater than the alcohol production amount attributable to
SP2’s premises for that year—

64.5.a

SP1 is the “larger producer”, and

64.5.b

SP2 is the “smaller producer”,

and vice versa.

64.6

If the amount mentioned in  subsection (5)  is equal in relation to both SP1’s
premises and SP2’s premises, either SP1 or SP2 may be treated as the “ larger
producer ” for the purposes of  this section .

64.7

In  subsections (1) ,  (5)  and  (6) , references to a person’s premises are
references to—

64.7.a

the premises on which the person produces alcoholic products immediately
before becoming connected with the other person mentioned in  section 61 (1) ,
if those premises are (at that time) non-group premises, or

64.7.b

if those premises are group premises, the production group which, at that
time, includes those premises (and the reference in  subsection (1)  to the
alcohol production amount in relation to those premises is a reference to the
aggregate of the alcohol production amount in relation to those premises and
every set of connected premises).

###### Early termination of merger transition period

65

65.1

This section  applies in relation to a post-merger production group if, in a
relevant year, Amount A is less than Amount B.

65.2

“Amount A” is the aggregate of the alcohol production amount, in relation to
every set of premises in the group, for the production year immediately
preceding the relevant year (determined in accordance with  section 57 ).

65.3

“Amount B” is the adjusted post-merger amount in the relevant year.

65.4

Neither the relevant year, nor any subsequent production year, is a merger
transition year in relation to the group.

65.5

Each of Year 1, 2 and 3 is a “ relevant year ” for the purposes of  this
section .

###### Subsequent mergers

66

66.1

This section  applies if—

66.1.a

a person who produces alcoholic products on group premises which are included
in a post-merger production group (the “first post-merger group”) becomes
connected with another person who produces alcoholic products (that are not
exempt from duty under any of  sections 72 ,  76  or  77 ), and

66.1.b

the producers mentioned in  paragraph (a)  become connected with one another
in Year 1, 2 or 3 in relation to the first post-merger group.

66.2

Neither the production year in which the producers mentioned in  subsection
(1) (a)  become connected with one another, nor any subsequent year, is a
merger transition year in relation to the first post-merger group.

66.3

But  subsection (2)  does not prevent the application of  sections 61  to  67
in relation to the post-merger production group that includes both of the
producers mentioned in  subsection (1) (a) .

###### Simultaneous mergers

67

67.1

Subsections (2)  to  (4)  apply if, at the same time as SP1 becomes connected
with SP2, SP1 also becomes connected with one or more other small producers
(who are not already connected with one another).

67.2

References in  sections 61  and  64  to SP2  include references to the other
small producers becoming connected with SP1.

67.3

For the purposes of  section 64 —

67.3.a

the “larger producer” is the producer with a greater alcohol production amount
attributable to the producer’s premises for the pre-merger year than any of
the other producers mentioned in  subsection (1) , and

67.3.b

each of the other producers is a “smaller producer”,

(and  this subsection  applies instead of  section 64 (5) ).

67.4

If the amount mentioned in  subsection (3) (a)  is equal in relation to any
two or more of the producers mentioned in  subsection (1) , any one of them
may be treated as the “ larger producer ” for the purposes of  section 64 .

###### Demergers

68

68.1

This section  applies if a demerger event occurs in relation to a production
group.

68.2

A “demerger event” occurs, in relation to a production group, if a group
producer (the “demerging producer”) ceases to be connected with at least one
other group producer.

68.3

A “ group producer ” in relation to a production group means a person who
produces alcoholic products on premises that are (immediately before the
demerger event) included in the production group.

68.4

For the purposes of the application of  sections 56  and  59  in relation to
the demerger year, the alcohol production amount for the immediately preceding
production year, in relation to production premises that were (immediately
before the demerger event) included in the group, is treated as being nil.

68.5

If, before the end of the restricted period, the demerging producer becomes
connected again with another group producer, none of  sections 61  to  67
apply by reference to that connection.

68.6

For the purposes of  subsection (5) , the “restricted period” is the period of
7 years beginning with the date on which the demerger event occurs.

68.7

Subsection (8)  applies if the demerger event occurs in Year 1, 2 or 3 in
relation to a post-merger production group (the “relevant group”).

68.8

Neither the production year in which the event occurs, nor any subsequent
year, is a merger transition year in relation to the relevant group.

68.9

References in  this section  to the “demerger year” are references to the
production year in which the demerger event occurs.

##### Interpretation of Chapter 3

###### “Producer”, “production premises”, “group premises” etc

69

69.1

This section  applies for the purposes of  this Chapter .

69.2

“ Production premises ” means premises (whether or not in the United Kingdom)
on which alcoholic products are produced.

69.3

Production premises are “group premises” at a time in a production year (the
“reference time”) if—

69.3.a

a person (“ P ”) who produces alcoholic products on the premises at the
reference time or at any earlier time in that year, or

69.3.b

a person connected with P,

also produces alcoholic products on any other premises at the reference time
or any earlier time in that year.

69.4

“ Connected premises ”, in relation to group premises, means premises on which
alcoholic products are produced at the reference time or at any earlier time
in the current year, by—

69.4.a

P, or

69.4.b

a person connected with P.

69.5

References to “ the production group ”, in relation to group premises, are
references to the group consisting of—

69.5.a

the group premises, and

69.5.b

every set of connected premises.

69.6

Production premises are “non-group premises” at a time in a production year
if, at that time, they are not group premises.

69.7

In  this Chapter —

69.7.a

references to the “ producer ”, in relation to a set of premises, are
references to the person who produces alcoholic products on those premises,
and

69.7.b

references to a “small producer” are references to a person who produces small
producer alcoholic products.

###### Connected persons

70

70.1

References in  this Chapter  to a person being or becoming connected with
another person are to be construed in accordance with section 1122 of CTA
2010.

70.2

But the Commissioners may, if they think it appropriate, treat two connected
persons as if they were not connected with one another for the purposes of
this Chapter .

###### Index of defined expressions: 

71

The following Table sets out expressions defined or explained for the purposes
of  this Chapter —

Expression Provision adjusted post-merger amount section 64 (1)  to  (3)
alcohol production amount section 57 (1) (a) connected premises section 69 (4)
current year section 54 (1) duty discount section 59 (1) estimated alcohol
production amount section 57 (1) (b) group premises section 69 (3) merger
transition year section 61 (4) non-group premises section 69 (6) post-merger
production group section 61 (3) post-merger production group premises section
61 (2) previous year section 54 (4) (b) producer (in  Chapter 3 ) section 69
(7) (a) production group section 69 (5) production premises section 69 (2)
production year section 54 (4) (a) small producer section 69 (7) (b) small
producer alcoholic products section 55 small production limit section 56 (4)
small production premises section 56  (for general purposes);  section 62  (in
relation to a post-merger production group) SP1 and SP2 section 61 (1) Year 1,
Year 2 and Year 3 section 61 (3)

#### Other reliefs and exemptions

##### General

###### Exemption: production for personal consumption

72

Alcohol duty is not charged on alcoholic products which—

72.a

are produced, in the United Kingdom, by a person who produces alcoholic
products only for the person’s own domestic use, and

72.b

are not spirits.

###### Research and experiments

73

73.1

This section  applies where—

73.1.a

alcohol duty is chargeable on alcoholic products produced in the United
Kingdom, and

73.1.b

the Commissioners are satisfied that the alcoholic products are to be used
only for the purposes of research into, or experiments in, the production of
alcoholic products.

73.2

The Commissioners may remit or repay the alcohol duty.

###### Spoilt alcoholic products

74

74.1

This section  applies where—

74.1.a

alcohol duty is chargeable on alcoholic products, and

74.1.b

the Commissioners are satisfied that the alcoholic products have become spoilt
or unfit for use.

74.2

The Commissioners may remit or repay the alcohol duty.

###### Alcoholic ingredients

75

75.1

  Subsection (2)  applies where a person proves to the satisfaction of the
Commissioners that—

75.1.a

alcohol duty is chargeable, and has been paid, on alcoholic products, and

75.1.b

the alcoholic products have been used as an ingredient in the production or
manufacture of—

75.1.b.i

a qualifying food product, or

75.1.b.ii

a beverage of an alcoholic strength of 1.2% or less.

75.2

The person is entitled to repayment of the alcohol duty, on making a claim in
accordance with  this section  (subject to  subsection (7) ).

75.3

In  this section  “ qualifying food product ” means—

75.3.a

vinegar,

75.3.b

chocolates containing alcohol, where 100 kilograms of the chocolates would not
contain more than 8.5 litres of alcohol, or

75.3.c

any other food (for human consumption) which contains alcohol, where 100
kilograms of the food would not contain more than 5 litres of alcohol.

75.4

Alcoholic products that are converted into vinegar are treated, for the
purposes of  this section , as being used as an ingredient in the production
or manufacture of vinegar.

75.5

Neither of the following is a qualifying food product for the purposes of this
section—

75.5.a

a beverage, including a beverage produced or intended for consumption in
frozen form;

75.5.b

a product that is intended for consumption as a substitute for a beverage.

75.6

A claim for repayment under  this section —

75.6.a

must be in the form and manner, and contain the information, required by the
Commissioners (either generally or in a particular case), and

75.6.b

except so far as the Commissioners otherwise allow, relate to duty paid on
alcoholic products used as an ingredient during a period of 3 months ending
not more than 3 years before the claim is made.

75.7

No repayment of duty may be made unless the Commissioners are satisfied that
the repayment claimed does not relate to any duty which has been repaid or
drawn back prior to the making of the claim.

75.8

The Commissioners may remit any alcohol duty chargeable—

75.8.a

on alcoholic products imported into the United Kingdom at a time when they are
contained as an ingredient in a qualifying food product within  subsection (3)
(b)  or  (c) , or

75.8.b

on alcoholic products used as an ingredient in the manufacture or production
in an excise warehouse of a qualifying food product within  subsection (3) (b)
or  (c) .

##### Spirits

###### Imported medical articles

76

76.1

Alcohol duty is not charged on spirits contained in medical articles imported
into the United Kingdom.

76.2

“ Medical article ” means an article recognised by the Commissioners as being
an article used for medical purposes.

###### Flavourings

77

77.1

Alcohol duty is not charged on spirits contained in food and drink
flavourings.

77.2

In  this section —

“ food and drink flavourings ” means any qualifying flavourings which are for
use in— the preparation of food for human consumption, or the preparation of
any beverage of an alcoholic strength not exceeding 1.2%; “ qualifying
flavourings ” means any products falling within commodity code 3302 of the
customs tariff established by regulations made under section 8 of TCTA 2018.

###### Authorised use for certain purposes

78

78.1

This section  applies where a person proposes to use spirits, on which alcohol
duty is chargeable, either—

78.1.a

in the manufacture or preparation of medical articles, or

78.1.b

for scientific purposes.

78.2

This section  also applies where—

78.2.a

a person proposes to use spirits, on which alcohol duty is chargeable, for the
purposes of art or manufacture (other than the manufacture of medical
articles), and

78.2.b

the Commissioners are satisfied that denatured alcohol would not be suitable
for that use.

78.3

The Commissioners may authorise the person to receive the spirits, and permit
the delivery of the spirits from relevant premises to that person, without
payment of the alcohol duty.

78.4

In  subsection (3) , “ relevant premises ” means—

78.4.a

an excise warehouse, or

78.4.b

premises in respect of which a person is approved (including premises on which
a person is authorised to hold alcoholic products without payment of duty)
under  section 82 .

78.5

An authorisation under  this section  may be given subject to the conditions
(if any)—

78.5.a

specified by the Commissioners in a notice published by them;

78.5.b

imposed by them in a particular case.

78.6

If a person fails to comply with a condition in respect of an authorisation,
the failure attracts a penalty under section 9 of FA 1994.

78.7

Subsection (8)  applies if—

78.7.a

the spirits are delivered to the person mentioned in  subsection (3) , and

78.7.b

the spirits are used otherwise than for the purpose in respect of which the
authorisation was given.

78.8

The Commissioners—

78.8.a

may assess as being alcohol duty due from the person an amount equal to the
alcohol duty that would have been charged on the spirits if, at the time of
delivery, no authorisation under  this section  had been given, and

78.8.b

must notify that person or the person’s representative of the assessment.

78.9

In  this section  “ medical article ” has the same meaning as in  section 76 .

###### Imported goods not for human consumption

79

79.1

The Commissioners may remit any alcohol duty chargeable on spirits imported
into the United Kingdom at a time when the spirits are contained in goods that
are not for human consumption.

79.2

If it turns out that the goods containing spirits are for human consumption,
the Commissioners—

79.2.a

may assess as being alcohol duty due from the relevant person an amount equal
to the alcohol duty that would (apart from  subsection (1) ) have been charged
on the goods, and

79.2.b

must notify the relevant person or that person’s representative of the
assessment.

79.3

For the purposes of  subsection (2) , references to “ the relevant person ”
are references to the importer.

###### Restrictions on use of certain articles

80

80.1

If a person makes unauthorised use of an article to which  this section
applies—

80.1.a

that conduct attracts a penalty under section 9 of FA 1994, and

80.1.b

the article is liable to forfeiture.

80.2

This section  applies to—

80.2.a

an article containing spirits which are exempt under  section 76  from the
charge to alcohol duty;

80.2.b

an article in respect of which spirits were used in the manufacture or
preparation, where remission of alcohol duty on the spirits was obtained under
section 78 .

80.3

A person makes “unauthorised use” of an article for the purposes of  this
section  if—

80.3.a

the person uses the article other than for medical or scientific purposes, and

80.3.b

the person has not complied with the requirements under  subsection (4) .

80.4

The requirements are that—

80.4.a

the person must obtain the written consent of the Commissioners to the use of
the article other than for medical or scientific purposes, and

80.4.b

the person must pay to the Commissioners an amount equal to the duty
shortfall.

80.5

In  this section , the “ duty shortfall ” means—

80.5.a

the difference between the duty charged on the spirits contained in, or used
in the manufacture or preparation of, the article, and

80.5.b

the duty which would have been chargeable had the article not been exempt
under  section 76  or the duty had not been remitted under  section 78 .

80.6

The Commissioners may make regulations for the purpose of enforcing  this
section .

80.7

Regulations under  subsection (6)  may, in particular, require a person
carrying on any trade in which spirits or articles containing, manufactured or
prepared with spirits are, in the opinion of the Commissioners, likely to be
or have been used—

80.7.a

to give and verify particulars of the materials which the person is using or
has used, or the articles the person has sold;

80.7.b

to produce any documents (of whatever nature) relating to such materials or
articles.

80.8

If a person contravenes or fails to comply with any regulation made under
subsection (6) , the contravention or failure attracts a penalty under section
9 of FA 1994.

80.9

In  this section , a reference to an article includes a reference to any part
of that article.

##### Remission and repayment

###### Further provision about remission and repayment

81

81.1

The remission or repayment of alcohol duty under any provision of  this
Chapter  is subject to the conditions (if any)—

81.1.a

specified by the Commissioners in a notice published by them;

81.1.b

specified by or under regulations made by them;

81.1.c

imposed by them in a particular case.

81.2

If a person fails to comply with a condition in respect of the remission or
repayment, the failure attracts a penalty under section 9 of FA 1994.

#### Regulated activities and approvals

##### Approval requirement: producers

82

82.1

A person may not produce alcoholic products on any premises unless—

82.1.a

the production on those premises is in accordance with an approval given under
this section  by the Commissioners to the person, or

82.1.b

the person is exempt from the approval requirement under  section 84  or  85 .

82.2

The Commissioners may approve a person under  this section  only if they are
satisfied that the person is a fit and proper person to produce alcoholic
products.

82.3

An approval under  this section  may authorise the approved person to hold
alcoholic products (including alcoholic products produced by another person
in, or imported into, the United Kingdom) on certain premises without payment
of alcohol duty.

82.4

A person may not carry out other activities on those premises in relation to
those alcoholic products, without payment of alcohol duty, except in
accordance with an approval under this section.

82.5

The reference in subsection (4) to “ activities ” includes, in particular,
packaging and processing, or carrying out other operations on or in relation
to, the alcoholic products.

##### Supplementary provision about approvals

83

83.1

An approval under  section 82  may be given to a person—

83.1.a

in respect of—

83.1.a.i

more than one category of alcoholic product;

83.1.a.ii

more than one set of premises;

83.1.b

for such period as the Commissioners think fit.

83.2

An approval is subject to the conditions or restrictions (if any)—

83.2.a

specified by the Commissioners in a notice published by them;

83.2.b

specified by or under regulations made by them;

83.2.c

imposed by them in a particular case.

83.3

The Commissioners may, at any time, revoke or vary the terms of an approval.

83.4

An application for approval must be in the form and manner, and contain the
information, specified by or under regulations made by the Commissioners.

##### Exemption: production for personal consumption

84

For the purposes of  section 82 (1) (b) , a person is exempt from the approval
requirement if—

84.a

the person produces alcoholic products only for the person’s own domestic use,
and

84.b

the alcoholic products are not spirits.

##### Exemption: research and experiments

85

For the purposes of  section 82 (1) (b) , a person is exempt from the approval
requirement if—

85.a

the person produces alcoholic products only for the purposes of research into,
or experiments in, the production of alcoholic products, and

85.b

the person complies with, and the alcoholic products are produced in
accordance with, the requirements specified—

85.b.i

by the Commissioners in a notice published by them, or

85.b.ii

by or under regulations made by the Commissioners.

##### Mixing alcoholic products

86

86.1

A person may not mix two or more alcoholic products unless one of the
following exemptions applies.

86.2

The first exemption applies if the products are mixed—

86.2.a

either—

86.2.a.i

in accordance with an approval under  section 82 , or

86.2.a.ii

in an excise warehouse, and

86.2.b

the mixing takes place before the excise duty point.

86.3

The second exemption applies if all of the alcoholic products being mixed—

86.3.a

fall within the same paragraph of  section 44 (1) , and

86.3.b

are of the same alcoholic strength.

86.4

The third exemption applies if—

86.4.a

the alcohol duty on each of the alcoholic products being mixed has been paid,
and

86.4.b

that amount is equal to or exceeds the amount of alcohol duty that would (if
the mixing had taken place before the excise duty point) have been chargeable
on the resulting mix.

86.5

The fourth exemption applies if—

86.5.a

the alcohol duty on each of the alcoholic products being mixed has been paid,

86.5.b

the resulting mix is intended for consumption on the premises on which the
mixing takes place, and

86.5.c

the method of mixing is of a description specified in a notice published by
the Commissioners.

##### Post-duty point dilution of alcoholic products

87

87.1

A person may not mix water or any other substance with alcoholic products on
which alcohol duty is chargeable if—

87.1.a

the mixing takes places after the excise duty point in relation to that
charge,

87.1.b

the resulting product is intended for sale, and

87.1.c

if the mixing had taken place immediately before the excise duty point, the
amount of alcohol duty would have been greater than the amount actually
payable.

87.2

This section  has effect, despite section 8 of the Isle of Man Act 1979, as if
a removal of relevant alcoholic products to the United Kingdom from the Isle
of Man constituted their importation into the United Kingdom (and references
to the charge to alcohol duty and to the excise duty point are to be read
accordingly).

##### Alcoholic products regulations

88

88.1

The Commissioners may by regulations (“ alcoholic products regulations ”) make
provision—

88.1.a

regulating the production, packaging, keeping and storage of alcoholic
products produced in, or imported into, the United Kingdom;

88.1.b

for determining when the production of any alcoholic product begins and when
it is completed;

88.1.c

for securing and collecting alcohol duty;

88.1.d

for determining alcohol duty, the rate and the method of charging the duty;

88.1.e

for charging alcohol duty, in specified circumstances, by reference to an
alcoholic strength which any alcoholic product might reasonably be expected to
have, or the rate of duty in force, at a time other than that at which the
alcoholic product becomes chargeable;

88.1.f

for determining the alcohol production amount in relation to a set of premises
(for the purposes of Chapter 3 of this Part), in specified circumstances, by
reference to an alcoholic strength which any alcoholic product might
reasonably be expected to have at a time other than that at which the
alcoholic product is produced;

88.1.g

for full or partial relief from alcohol duty in specified circumstances (and
whether or not subject to conditions);

88.1.h

regulating or prohibiting the addition of substances to, the mixing of, or the
carrying out of other operations on or in relation to, any alcoholic product;

88.1.i

regulating the approval of persons under this Chapter, including the variation
or revocation of the approval or of any condition or restriction to which it
is subject;

88.1.j

permitting, in specified circumstances, the removal of alcoholic products from
certain premises without payment of duty (whether or not subject to
conditions);

88.1.k

make provision in respect of alcoholic products permitted to be removed from
premises without payment of duty or on which alcohol duty has been remitted;

88.1.l

regulating the transportation of alcoholic products;

88.1.m

requiring the production of certificates as to matters relating to alcoholic
products imported into the United Kingdom, and the production and producer of
those products, as evidence that conditions for charging the duty at a
particular rate are satisfied.

88.2

Alcoholic products regulations may, in particular, include provision—

88.2.a

requiring the making of returns;

88.2.b

for notifications and other communications with the Commissioners to be made
electronically;

88.2.c

requiring persons to keep, and make available for inspection, specified
records relating to alcoholic products;

88.2.d

for the imposition under the regulations of requirements as to documents to
accompany, or be provided with, alcohol products at any time during a
specified period or in specified circumstances, and requiring production of
those documents;

88.2.e

conferring powers on an officer of Revenue and Customs to inspect, copy or
remove for a reasonable period records or documents relating to alcoholic
products;

88.2.f

for assessing an amount as alcohol duty due from a person in specified
circumstances;

88.2.g

for the imposition under the regulations of conditions and restrictions (which
may include a requirement to give a guarantee or other security).

88.3

The reference in  subsection (1) (k)  to alcoholic products permitted to be
removed from premises without payment of duty is treated as including a
reference to alcoholic products that are—

88.3.a

treated for the purposes of alcohol duty, by provision made (or having effect
as if made) under section 12 of the Customs and Excise Duties (General
Reliefs) Act 1979 (supply of duty-free goods to His Majesty’s ships), as
exported,

88.3.b

supplied to persons on whom relief from payment of alcohol duty is conferred
by provision made under section 13A of that Act (reliefs from duties and taxes
for persons enjoying certain immunities and privileges), or

88.3.c

supplied for use on a ship, aircraft or railway vehicle as stores, in
accordance with provision made under section 60A of CEMA 1979 (power to make
regulations about stores).

88.4

In this section, “ specified ” means specified by or under alcoholic products
regulations.

##### Penalties and forfeiture

89

89.1

This section  applies if a person contravenes or fails to comply with—

89.1.a

section 82 ,

89.1.b

section 86 (1) ,

89.1.c

section 87 (1) , or

89.1.d

any provision made by or under alcoholic products regulations.

89.2

The person’s conduct attracts a penalty under section 9 of FA 1994.

89.3

Any alcoholic products, articles (including packaging or equipment) or
substances in the person's possession, used (or which may be used) for or in
connection with an action to which the contravention or failure relates, are
liable to forfeiture.

#### Denatured alcohol

##### Denatured alcohol

90

90.1

Alcohol duty is not charged on denatured alcohol.

90.2

“ Denatured alcohol ” means an alcoholic product which has been mixed with a
substance, and in a manner, specified by or under regulations made by the
Commissioners (and references, however expressed, to “denaturing” alcoholic
products are to be construed accordingly).

90.3

Provision made under  subsection (2)  may include provision specifying a
substance, or a manner of mixing, by reference to particular circumstances or
other factors, or to the approval or opinion of specified persons.

90.4

Where—

90.4.a

alcohol duty is chargeable on alcoholic products, and

90.4.b

the Commissioners are satisfied that the alcoholic products are to be
converted into denatured alcohol before the duty is required to be paid,

the duty is to be remitted.

##### Licence to manufacture and deal wholesale in denatured alcohol

91

91.1

A person may not denature any alcoholic products, or deal wholesale in
denatured alcohol, unless the person holds an excise licence as a denaturer
under  this section .

91.2

For the purposes of  this section , a person deals wholesale in denatured
alcohol if the person sells, at any one time to any one person—

91.2.a

a quantity of at least 20 litres of denatured alcohol, or

91.2.b

a smaller quantity, specified by or under regulations made by the
Commissioners, of denatured alcohol.

91.3

The Commissioners may, at any time, revoke or suspend an excise licence under
this section .

91.4

An application for an excise licence as a denaturer must be in the form and
manner, and contain the information, specified by the Commissioners in a
notice published by them.

##### Regulations relating to denatured alcohol

92

92.1

The Commissioners may, with a view to the protection of the revenue, by
regulations make provision—

92.1.a

regulating the denaturing of alcoholic products;

92.1.b

regulating the supply, storage, removal, sale, delivery, receipt, use, export
or shipment as stores of denatured alcohol;

92.1.c

permitting alcoholic products to be denatured in a warehouse;

92.1.d

permitting dealing wholesale (within the meaning of  section 91 ) in denatured
alcohol of a specified description, in specified circumstances, without an
excise licence;

92.1.e

regulating the import, receipt, removal, storage and use of alcoholic products
for denaturing;

92.1.f

regulating the storage and removal of substances to be used in denaturing
alcoholic products;

92.1.g

about the manner in which account is to be kept of stocks of denatured alcohol
in the possession of persons licensed as denaturers under  section 91  and of
retailers of denatured alcohol.

92.2

Regulations under  this section  may, in particular, include provision—

92.2.a

for applications and other communications with the Commissioners to be made
electronically;

92.2.b

requiring persons licensed as denaturers under  section 91  and retailers of
denatured alcohol to keep, and make available for inspection, specified
records relating to denaturing;

92.2.c

conferring powers on an officer of Revenue and Customs to inspect, copy or
remove for a reasonable period those records;

92.2.d

for the imposition under the regulations of conditions and restrictions (which
may include a requirement to give a guarantee or other security).

92.3

In this section, “ specified ” means specified by or under regulations under
this section.

##### Penalties and forfeiture

93

93.1

This section  applies if a person—

93.1.a

fails to comply with  section 91 (1)  (denaturing alcoholic products, or
dealing wholesale in denatured alcohol, otherwise than in accordance with an
excise licence), or

93.1.b

contravenes or fails to comply with any provision made by or under regulations
under  section 92 .

93.2

Conduct mentioned in  subsection (1) (a)  or  (b)  attracts a penalty under
section 9 of FA 1994.

93.3

Any alcoholic product or denatured alcohol, article (including packaging or
equipment) or substance in the person’s possession, used (or which may be
used) for or in connection with an action to which the contravention or
failure relates is liable to forfeiture.

##### Defaults in respect of denatured alcohol: possession of excess alcoholic products

94

94.1

This section  applies if, in relation to a person who holds an excise licence
under  section 91  (the “denaturer”), at a time when an account is taken of
the quantity of denatured alcohol in the denaturer’s possession—

94.1.a

there is a difference between the actual amount and the proper amount, and

94.1.b

either—

94.1.b.i

where the actual amount exceeds the proper amount, the amount of the excess is
more than 1% of the permitted amount, or

94.1.b.ii

where the proper amount exceeds the actual amount, the amount of the excess is
more than 2% of the permitted amount.

94.2

For the purposes of  subsection (1) —

94.2.a

the “actual amount” is the quantity of alcoholic products of any description
in the denatured alcohol in the denaturer’s possession;

94.2.b

the “proper amount” is the quantity of alcoholic products of the same
description which, according to any accounts that are required to be kept by
or under any regulations under  section 92 , ought to be in the denatured
alcohol in the denaturer’s possession.

94.3

Where there is a difference between the actual amount and the proper amount,
in relation to alcoholic products of a particular description, the “permitted
amount” is the aggregate of—

94.3.a

the quantity of alcoholic products of that description when an account was
last taken, and

94.3.b

the quantity of alcoholic products of that description that have since been
lawfully added to the denaturer’s stock.

94.4

In a case within  subsection (1) (b) (i) , the relevant amount of any
alcoholic products of the description to which the difference relates in the
denaturer’s possession is liable to forfeiture.

94.5

The “ relevant amount ” for the purposes of  subsection (4)  is the amount
corresponding to the amount of the excess mentioned in  subsection (1) (b) (i)
, or such smaller amount as the Commissioners consider appropriate.

94.6

In a case within  subsection (1) (b) (ii) , the denaturer must, on demand by
the Commissioners, pay alcohol duty—

94.6.a

on the amount of alcoholic products (of the same description) equal to the
amount of the difference, or

94.6.b

if the Commissioners specify a smaller amount of alcoholic products (of the
same description) in the demand, on that amount.

94.7

A demand made for the purposes of  this section  is to be combined, as if
there had been a default of a kind mentioned in section 12 of FA 1994
(assessments to excise duty) with an assessment and notification under that
section of the amount of duty due in consequence of the demand.

##### Defaults in respect of denatured alcohol: supply and use of denatured alcohol

95

95.1

This section  applies if a person, in contravention of regulations under
section 92 , uses or supplies denatured alcohol containing alcoholic products
of any description.

95.2

The person must, on demand by the Commissioners, pay alcohol duty—

95.2.a

on the amount of alcoholic products contained, at the time of supply or use,
in the denatured alcohol, or

95.2.b

if the Commissioners specify a smaller amount of alcoholic products (of the
same description) in the demand, on that amount.

95.3

For the purposes of  this section , a supply of denatured alcohol to a person
who—

95.3.a

by reason of regulations under  section 92  is prohibited from receiving it
unless authorised to do so by or under the regulations, but

95.3.b

is not so authorised,

is treated as being a supply in contravention of those regulations.

95.4

A demand made for the purposes of  this section  is to be combined, as if
there had been a default of a kind mentioned in section 12 of FA 1994
(assessments to excise duty) with an assessment and notification under that
section of the amount of duty due in consequence of the demand.

##### Inspection of premises etc

96

96.1

An officer of Revenue and Customs may, at any reasonable time—

96.1.a

enter and inspect the premises of a person authorised by regulations under
section 92  to receive denatured alcohol,

96.1.b

inspect and examine any denatured alcohol on the premises, and

96.1.c

take samples of any denatured alcohol or of any goods containing denatured
alcohol (paying a reasonable price for each sample).

96.2

Subsection (1)  does not affect any other power conferred by the customs and
excise Acts.

##### Prohibition of use of denatured alcohol etc as beverage or medicine

97

97.1

It is an offence for a person—

97.1.a

to prepare, or attempt to prepare, denatured alcohol for use as a beverage or
as a mixture with a beverage;

97.1.b

to sell denatured alcohol (whether or not prepared as described in  paragraph
(a) ) as a beverage or mixed with a beverage;

97.1.c

to use any denatured alcohol or a derivative of it in the preparation of any
article capable of being used as a beverage;

97.1.d

to sell or possess any article capable of being used as described in
paragraph (c) , in the preparation of which denatured alcohol or any
derivative of it has been used;

97.1.e

except as permitted by the Commissioners and in accordance with any conditions
imposed by them—

97.1.e.i

to purify, or attempt to purify, denatured alcohol, or

97.1.e.ii

after denatured alcohol has once been used, to attempt to recover the spirit
or alcohol contained in it by distillation, condensation or in any other
manner.

97.2

Subsection (1)  is subject to  subsections (5)  and  (6) .

97.3

A person who commits an offence under  this section  is liable on summary
conviction to a penalty not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.

97.4

Any denatured alcohol, or any article (including packaging or equipment), in
respect of which an offence under  this section  is committed is liable to
forfeiture.

97.5

No offence is committed under  this section  where a person uses denatured
alcohol or any derivative of it—

97.5.a

in the preparation for use as a medical article (as defined in  section 76 ),

97.5.b

in the making of anything sold or supplied in accordance with regulations made
by the Commissioners under  section 92 , or

97.5.c

in art or manufacture.

97.6

No offence is committed under  this section  where a person sells or possesses
anything that—

97.6.a

is permitted to be prepared or made, by reference to  paragraph (a)  or  (b)
of  subsection (5) , for a use described in that paragraph, and

97.6.b

is sold or possessed for that use.

97.7

In  this section , references to denatured alcohol include references to—

97.7.a

methanol, and

97.7.b

any mixture containing denatured alcohol or methanol.

#### Wholesaling of controlled alcoholic products

##### Definitions

98

98.1

This section  defines certain expressions used in  this Chapter .

98.2

A sale is of “controlled alcoholic products” if—

98.2.a

it is a sale of alcoholic products on which alcohol duty is charged under
this Part  at a rate greater than nil, and

98.2.b

the excise duty point for the alcoholic products falls at or before the time
of the sale.

98.3

Controlled alcoholic products are sold “wholesale” if—

98.3.a

the sale is of any quantity of the alcoholic products,

98.3.b

the seller is carrying on a trade or business and the sale is made in the
course of that trade or business,

98.3.c

the sale is to a buyer carrying on a trade or business, for sale or supply in
the course of that trade or business, and

98.3.d

the sale is not an incidental sale, a group sale or an excluded sale,

and a reference to buying controlled alcoholic products wholesale is to be
read accordingly.

98.4

A sale is an “incidental sale” if—

98.4.a

the seller makes authorised retail sales of alcoholic products of any
description, and

98.4.b

the sale is incidental to those sales.

98.5

A sale is an “authorised retail sale” if it is made by retail under and in
accordance with a licence or other authorisation under an enactment regulating
the sale and supply of alcohol.

98.6

A sale is a “group sale” if the seller and the buyer are both bodies corporate
which are members of the same group (see  section 106 ).

98.7

A sale is an “excluded sale” if it is of a description specified by or under
regulations made by the Commissioners.

98.8

“ Controlled activity ” means—

98.8.a

selling controlled alcoholic products wholesale,

98.8.b

offering or exposing controlled alcoholic products for sale in circumstances
in which the sale (if made) would be a wholesale sale, or

98.8.c

arranging in the course of a trade or business for controlled alcoholic
products to be sold wholesale, or offered or exposed for sale in circumstances
in which the sale (if made) would be a wholesale sale.

98.9

“ UK person ” means a person who is UK-established for the purposes of value
added tax (see paragraph 1(10) of Schedule 1 to VATA 1994).

98.10

“ Enactment ” includes an enactment contained in—

98.10.a

an Act of the Scottish Parliament;

98.10.b

an Act or Measure of Senedd Cymru;

98.10.c

Northern Ireland legislation.

98.11

References in  this Chapter  to the “alcohol wholesaling provisions” are
references to  this section  and  sections 99  to  106 , and  Schedule 10 .

##### Further provision relating to definitions

99

99.1

The Commissioners may by regulations make provision as to the cases in which
sales are, or are not, to be treated for the purposes of  this Chapter  as—

99.1.a

wholesale sales,

99.1.b

sales of controlled alcoholic products,

99.1.c

incidental sales,

99.1.d

authorised retail sales, or

99.1.e

group sales.

99.2

The Commissioners may by regulations make provision as to the cases in which a
person is, or is not, to be treated for the purposes of  this Chapter  as
carrying on a controlled activity by virtue of  section 98 (8) (b)  or  (c) .

##### Approval to carry on controlled activity

100

100.1

A UK person may not carry on a controlled activity otherwise than in
accordance with an approval given by the Commissioners under  this section .

100.2

The Commissioners may approve a person under  this section  to carry on a
controlled activity only if they are satisfied that the person is a fit and
proper person to carry on the activity.

100.3

The Commissioners may approve a person under  this section  to carry on a
controlled activity for such period as they think fit.

100.4

An approval may be given subject to the conditions or restrictions (if any)—

100.4.a

specified by the Commissioners in a notice published by them;

100.4.b

specified by or under regulations made by them;

100.4.c

imposed by them in a particular case.

100.5

The conditions or restrictions may include conditions or restrictions
requiring the controlled activity to be carried on only at or from premises
specified or approved by the Commissioners.

100.6

The Commissioners may at any time revoke or vary the terms of an approval
under  this section .

100.7

In  this Chapter  “ approved wholesaler ” means a person approved under  this
section  to carry on a controlled activity.

##### The register of approved wholesalers

101

101.1

The Commissioners must maintain a register of approved wholesalers.

101.2

The register is to contain such information relating to approved wholesalers
as the Commissioners consider appropriate.

101.3

The Commissioners may make publicly available such information contained in
the register as they consider necessary to enable those who deal with a person
who carries on a controlled activity to determine whether the person in
question is an approved wholesaler for the purposes of that activity.

101.4

The information may be made available by such means as the Commissioners
consider appropriate.

##### Regulations relating to approval, registration and controlled activities

102

102.1

The Commissioners may by regulations make provision—

102.1.a

regulating the approval and registration of persons under the alcohol
wholesaling provisions,

102.1.b

regulating the variation or revocation of any such approval or registration or
of any condition or restriction to which such an approval or registration is
subject,

102.1.c

about the register maintained under  section 101 ,

102.1.d

regulating the carrying on of controlled activities, and

102.1.e

imposing obligations on approved wholesalers.

102.2

The regulations may, in particular, make provision—

102.2.a

requiring applications, and other communications with the Commissioners, to be
made electronically;

102.2.b

as to the procedure for the approval and registration of bodies corporate
which are members of the same group and for members of such a group to be
jointly and severally liable for any penalties imposed under—

102.2.b.i

the regulations, or

102.2.b.ii

Schedule 10 ;

102.2.c

requiring approved wholesalers to keep and make available for inspection such
records relating to controlled activities as may be specified by or under the
regulations;

102.2.d

conferring powers on an officer of Revenue and Customs to inspect, copy or
remove for a reasonable period those records;

102.2.e

imposing a penalty of an amount specified by the regulations (which must not
exceed £1,000) for a contravention of—

102.2.e.i

the regulations, or

102.2.e.ii

any condition or restriction imposed under the alcohol wholesaling provisions;

102.2.f

for the assessment and recovery of such a penalty;

102.2.g

for alcoholic products (whether or not charged with any duty and whether or
not that duty has been paid) to be subject to forfeiture for a contravention
of—

102.2.g.i

the alcohol wholesaling provisions or the regulations made under  this section
, or

102.2.g.ii

any condition or restriction imposed under the alcohol wholesaling provisions.

##### Restriction on buying controlled alcoholic products wholesale

103

103.1

A person may not—

103.1.a

buy controlled alcoholic products wholesale from a UK person, unless the
person is an approved wholesaler in relation to the sale, or

103.1.b

buy relevant alcoholic products from an Isle of Man person, unless the person
is an Isle of Man approved wholesaler.

103.2

In  this section  and in  section 104 (4) —

103.2.a

“ Isle of Man person ” means a person who is established in the Isle of Man
for the purposes of value added tax under any provision of the law in force in
the Isle of Man corresponding to paragraph 1(10) of Schedule 1 to VATA 1994;

103.2.b

“ Isle of Man approved wholesaler ” means an Isle of Man person who is
approved under any provision of the law in force in the Isle of Man
corresponding to  section 100 ;

103.2.c

“ relevant alcoholic products ” means alcoholic products which, if they had
been produced in the United Kingdom, would have been charged with alcohol duty
under  this Part  at a rate greater than nil.

##### Offences

104

104.1

A person who contravenes  section 100 (1)  by selling controlled alcoholic
products wholesale commits an offence if the person knows or has reasonable
grounds to suspect that—

104.1.a

the buyer is carrying on a trade or business, and

104.1.b

the alcoholic products are for sale or supply in the course of that trade or
business.

104.2

A person who contravenes  section 100 (1)  by offering or exposing controlled
alcoholic products for sale in circumstances in which the sale (if made) would
be a wholesale sale commits an offence if the person intends to make a
wholesale sale of the alcoholic products.

104.3

A person who contravenes  section 100 (1)  by arranging in the course of a
trade or business for controlled alcoholic products to be sold wholesale, or
offered or exposed for sale in circumstances in which the sale (if made) would
be a wholesale sale, commits an offence if the person intends to arrange for
the alcoholic products to be sold wholesale.

104.4

A person who contravenes  section 103  commits an offence if the person knows
or has reasonable grounds to suspect that—

104.4.a

the UK person from whom the controlled alcoholic products are bought is not an
approved wholesaler in relation to the sale, or

104.4.b

the Isle of Man person from whom the relevant alcoholic products are bought is
not an Isle of Man approved wholesaler in relation to the sale.

104.5

A person who commits an offence under  this section  is liable on summary
conviction—

104.5.a

in England and Wales to—

104.5.a.i

imprisonment for a term not exceeding the general limit in a magistrates’
court,

104.5.a.ii

a fine, or

104.5.a.iii

both,

104.5.b

in Scotland to—

104.5.b.i

imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months,

104.5.b.ii

a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or

104.5.b.iii

both, and

104.5.c

in Northern Ireland to—

104.5.c.i

imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months,

104.5.c.ii

a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or

104.5.c.iii

both.

104.6

A person who commits an offence under  this section  is liable on conviction
on indictment to—

104.6.a

imprisonment for a period not exceeding 7 years,

104.6.b

a fine, or

104.6.c

both.

##### Penalties

105

Schedule 10  contains provision about penalties for contraventions of the
alcohol wholesaling provisions.

##### Groups

106

106.1

Two or more bodies corporate are members of a group for the purposes of the
alcohol wholesaling provisions if each is established or has a fixed
establishment in the United Kingdom and—

106.1.a

one of them controls each of the others,

106.1.b

one person (whether a body corporate or an individual) controls all of them,
or

106.1.c

two or more individuals carrying on a business in partnership control all of
them.

106.2

For the purposes of  this section , a body corporate is to be taken to control
another body corporate if—

106.2.a

it is empowered by or under an enactment to control that body’s activities, or

106.2.b

it is that body’s holding company within the meaning of section 1159 of, and
Schedule 6 to, the Companies Act 2006.

106.3

For the purposes of  this section —

106.3.a

an individual or individuals are to be taken to control a body corporate if
the individual or individuals (were the individual or individuals a company)
would be that body’s holding company within the meaning of section 1159 of,
and Schedule 6 to, the Companies Act 2006 (meaning of “subsidiary” etc), and

106.3.b

a body corporate is established or has a fixed establishment in the United
Kingdom if it is so established or has such an establishment for the purposes
of value added tax.

##### Removal of goods: application of section 95 of CEMA 1979

110

110.1

Section 95 of CEMA 1979 (deficiency in goods occurring in course of removal
from warehouse without payment of duty) is amended as follows.

110.2

After subsection (1) insert—

110.2.1A

Subsection (1) applies in relation to goods that are alcoholic products as if
references, in that subsection and in section 94, to a “warehouse” included
references to premises in respect of which a person is authorised, under
section 82 of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023, to hold alcoholic products without
payment of duty (and references to “warehoused” are to be construed
accordingly).

110.2.1B

Subsection (1) applies (as modified by subsection (1A)) in relation to
alcoholic products on which alcohol duty has been remitted as it applies to
alcoholic products lawfully permitted to be taken from premises as mentioned
in that subsection.

110.3

insert  “, (1A) or (1B)” .

##### Drawback

111

111.1

This section  applies where drawback of alcohol duty is allowable, under
regulations made under section 60A of CEMA 1979 (power to make regulations
about stores) or section 2 of F(No. 2)A 1992 (power to provide for drawback of
excise duty), to a person who produces alcoholic products in accordance with
an approval under  section 82  (“the producer”).

111.2

Subject to the conditions (if any) that the Commissioners impose, drawback of
alcohol duty may be set against any amount to which the producer is chargeable
in respect of alcohol duty (and any reference in CEMA 1979 to drawback payable
is to be construed in accordance with  this section ).

##### Transitional provision

###### Temporary provision: wine

115

115.1

Wine of an alcoholic strength of at least 11.5% but not exceeding 14.5% is
treated, for the purposes of the charge to alcohol duty, as if it were of an
alcoholic strength of 12.5%.

115.2

This section expires at the end of the period of 18 months beginning with the
day on which  section 48  (rates) comes into force.

###### Temporary provision: cider

116

Alcohol duty is not charged on cider which is produced—

116.a

at a time before  section 82  (approvals) comes into force, and

116.b

by a person who, at that time, is exempt from the requirement to register
under section 62 of ALDA 1979 by reason of an order made (or having effect as
if made) under subsection (3) of that section.

##### Regulations: procedure

119

119.1

A statutory instrument containing any regulations made under  section 46 (a)
or section  51 (5)  must be laid before the House of Commons, and, unless
approved by that House before the end of the period of 28 days beginning with
the date on which the instrument is made, ceases to have effect at the end of
that period.

119.2

The fact that a statutory instrument ceases to have effect as a result of
subsection (1)  does not affect—

119.2.a

anything previously done under the instrument, or

119.2.b

the making of a new statutory instrument.

119.3

In calculating the period for the purposes of  subsection (1) , no account is
to be taken of any time—

119.3.a

during which Parliament is dissolved or prorogued, or

119.3.b

during which the House of Commons is adjourned for more than 4 days.

119.4

A statutory instrument containing (whether alone or with other provision) any
regulations made under  paragraph 2  of  Schedule 12  may not be made unless a
draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of,
the House of Commons.

119.5

A statutory instrument containing regulations made under  this Part , other
than regulations in respect of which  subsection (1)  or  subsection (4)
applies, is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the House of
Commons.

119.6

A statutory instrument containing regulations to which  subsection (1)
applies may also include regulations relating to alcohol duty under any other
provision of the customs and excise Acts (including any provision of  this
Part ) if the Parliamentary procedure applicable to a statutory instrument
containing regulations under the other provision does not require House of
Commons approval.

119.7

Where regulations are included as mentioned in  subsection (6) , the procedure
applicable to the statutory instrument is the procedure mentioned in
subsection (1)  (and not the procedure mentioned in  subsection (6) ).

119.8

If—

119.8.a

a statutory instrument contains regulations under any provision of  this Part
(other than regulations in respect of which  subsection (1)  or  subsection
(4)  applies) and regulations relating to alcohol duty under any other
provision of the customs and excise Acts, and

119.8.b

the Parliamentary procedure applicable to a statutory instrument containing
provision under the other provision does not require House of Commons
approval,

the only Parliamentary procedure applicable to a statutory instrument
mentioned in  paragraph (a)  is that given by  this section .

119.9

For the purposes of  subsection (6)  and  subsection (8)  the Parliamentary
procedure applicable to a statutory instrument requires House of Commons
approval if, as a condition of its continuing to have effect or its making,
the House of Commons has to approve the statutory instrument or a draft of it.

119.10

This section  does not apply to regulations under  section 120 .

120

120.1

The following provisions of  this Part  come into force on the day on which

120.1.a

this Chapter , and

120.1.b

120.4

The Commissioners may by regulations make consequential, supplementary,

120.5

The power to make regulations under  subsection (4) —

120.5.a

may be exercised so as to make different provision for different purposes or

120.5.b

includes power to make provision of a kind described in  section 118 (3) (a)
to  (c) .

120.6

Regulations under  this section  are to be made by statutory instrument.

### Multinational top-up tax

#### Introduction and charge

##### Introduction to multinational top-up tax

121

121.1

The purpose of  this Part  is to implement the provisions of the Pillar Two
rules relating to top-up tax under the IIR (within the meaning of those
rules).

121.2

For that purpose,  this Part  makes provision for a tax payable in respect of
members of multinational groups who are located in territories (outside the
United Kingdom) where their rate of tax (as determined in accordance with
this Part ) is less than 15%.

121.3

The tax is to be known as “ multinational top-up tax ”.

121.4

Sections 122  to  124  set out the charge to multinational top-up tax and
describe how it is to be calculated.

121.5

Chapter 2  of  this Part —

121.5.a

sets out the meaning of “multinational group”;

121.5.b

describes who the members of such a group are;

121.5.c

identifies the ultimate parent of such a group;

121.5.d

limits the application of  this Part  to multinational groups with an annual
revenue of at least 750 million euros and that have at least one member in the
United Kingdom (such a group is referred to in  this Part  as “qualifying”);

121.5.e

sets out how to determine which members of a multinational group (“responsible
members”) are responsible for paying the tax and which members they are
responsible for.

##### Chargeable persons

122

122.1

A person is chargeable to multinational top-up tax for an accounting period of
a multinational group if the group is a qualifying multinational group in that
period and—

122.1.a

the person—

122.1.a.i

is a responsible member of the multinational group at any time in that period,

122.1.a.ii

is a body corporate or a partnership  ..., and

122.1.a.iii

is located in the United Kingdom, or

122.1.b
