###### Investment strategy condition

13

13.1

In paragraph 13 (activity and investment strategy conditions), after sub-
paragraph (2) insert—

13.1.3

A company (“ C ”) may make an election under this sub-paragraph that all
relevant equity securities held by C are to be treated as if they were not
equity securities listed or traded on a recognised stock exchange or any other
public market or exchange for the purposes of—

13.1.3.a

the investment strategy condition as it applies to C, and

13.1.3.b

that condition as it applies to any other company with a relevant interest in
C.

13.1.4

Equity securities are “relevant” if—

13.1.4.a

they are listed or traded on a recognised stock exchange or any other public
market or exchange,

13.1.4.b

they are held directly by C,

13.1.4.c

they were not acquired at a time when the election had effect from a company
that is a member of the same group as C, other than a company that was a QAHC
at the time of the acquisition, and

13.1.4.d

where C has previously been and ceased being a QAHC, they were acquired after
the most recent occasion on which C became a QAHC.

13.1.5

An election under  sub-paragraph (3) —

13.1.5.a

must be notified to HMRC,

13.1.5.b

has effect only while the company is a QAHC,

13.1.5.c

is revoked on the company ceasing to be a QAHC, and

13.1.5.d

may not otherwise be revoked.

13.1.6

Where an election under  sub-paragraph (3)  has effect, any dividend or other
distribution received by C in respect of relevant equity securities that would
otherwise be exempt for the purposes of section 931A(1) of CTA 2009 (charge to
tax on distributions received) is to be treated as not exempt for the purposes
of that section.

13.1.7

Where—

13.1.7.a

C disposes of relevant equity securities (“the dispossessed securities”), and

13.1.7.b

within the period of thirty days after the disposal, C acquires securities
(“the acquired securities”) of the same class,

any dividend or other distribution received by a person in respect of holding
the acquired securities in the period (“the dispossession period”) commencing
with the disposal by C of the dispossessed securities and ending with the
acquisition by C of the acquired securities is to be treated as having been
received by C for Corporation Tax purposes.

13.1.8

But the amount of any dividend or other distribution treated as received by C
as a result of sub-paragraph  (7)  is limited to the amount of the dividend or
other distribution C would have received had C held the dispossessed
securities throughout the dispossession period.

13.1.9

Equity securities are not to be treated as being of the same class unless they
are so treated by the practice of the recognised stock exchange, other public
market or exchange they are listed or traded on.

13.2

Omit paragraph 35 (and the italic heading before it).

13.3

In paragraph 58, after sub-paragraph (2) insert—

13.3.3

In this Schedule, apart from in paragraphs 42 and 43 (worldwide groups),
references to a company being a member of a group of companies are to be read
in accordance with section 170 of TCGA 1992 (interpretation of sections 171 to
181 of that Act: groups).

###### Alternative finance arrangements

15

15.1

After paragraph 58 insert—

############ Alternative finance arrangements

15.1.59

15.1.59.1

Sub-paragraph  (2)  applies for the purposes of determining the amounts of
relevant interests in companies in accordance with paragraphs 3 to 6 and the
provisions of Chapter 6 of Part 6 of CTA 2010 applied by those paragraphs.

15.1.59.2

Where a person has (in substance) a beneficial entitlement to the profits of a
company as a result of qualifying alternative finance arrangements—

15.1.59.2.a

that entitlement is to be treated as an entitlement to a proportion of the
profits of that company available for distribution to equity holders of the
company, and

15.1.59.2.b

that person is to be treated as an equity holder.

15.1.59.3

“ Qualifying alternative finance arrangements ” means arrangements—

15.1.59.3.a

that constitute alternative finance arrangements for the purposes of Chapter 6
of Part 6 of CTA 2009 (alternative finance arrangements), or

15.1.59.3.b

that do not constitute alternative finance arrangements only as a result of
section 508 of that Act (exclusion provision not at arms length).

15.1.59.4

But arrangements that are analogous to a normal commercial loan are not
qualifying alternative finance arrangements.

15.1.59.5

Arrangements are analogous to a normal commercial loan if, were the
arrangements structured as a loan that resulted in the same or similar
entitlements of the parties to the arrangements, they would constitute a
normal commercial loan within the meaning of section 162 of CTA 2010.

15.2

15.2.5A

finance arrangements who are equivalent to equity holders to be treated as
such.

15.3

but see also paragraph 59 of this Schedule” .

###### Assessments relating to corporation tax

2

In Part 5 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 (determinations and assessments), after
paragraph 49 insert—

########## Transfer pricing records: carelessness

2.49A

2.49A.1

This paragraph applies where—

2.49A.1.a

the situation mentioned in paragraph 41(1) or (2) has been brought about by a
person within any of paragraphs (a) to (c) of paragraph 43 (“ P ”) as regards
a relevant accounting period of a company,

2.49A.1.b

the situation relates to the calculation of profits or losses in accordance
with Part 4 of TIOPA 2010 (transfer pricing) for the purposes of that period,
and

2.49A.1.c

the company has failed to comply, in relation to specified relevant transfer
pricing records that relate to the calculation, with either or both of—

2.49A.1.c.i

paragraph 21 (duty to keep and preserve records), and

2.49A.1.c.ii

an information notice (within the meaning of Schedule 36 to the Finance Act
2008 (information and inspection powers)).

2.49A.2

It is to be presumed for the purposes of this Part of this Schedule that the
situation mentioned in paragraph 41(1) or (2) was brought about carelessly by
P, unless—

2.49A.2.a

the situation was brought about deliberately by P, or

2.49A.2.b

the company satisfies HMRC or (on an appeal notified to the tribunal) the
tribunal that P took reasonable care to avoid the situation.

2.49A.3

For the purposes of this paragraph—

2.49A.3.a

“ relevant accounting period of a company ” means an accounting period in
respect of which—

2.49A.3.a.i

the company, together with one or more other enterprises, constitutes an MNE
Group within the meaning of the Taxes (Base Erosion and Profit Shifting)
(Country-by-Country Reporting) Regulations 2016 ( S.I. 2016/237 ) (see
regulation 2(3) of those Regulations), and

2.49A.3.a.ii

the MNE Group meets the threshold requirement within the meaning of those
Regulations (see regulations 3(2) to (4) of those Regulations);

2.49A.3.b

records are “specified relevant transfer pricing records” if—

2.49A.3.b.i

they are relevant transfer pricing records specified, or of a description
specified, in regulations under paragraph 21 (duties to keep and preserve
records), and

2.49A.3.b.ii

the company is required to keep and preserve those records under that
paragraph.

4

In Part 4 of TMA 1970 (assessment and claims), after section 30B insert—

########## Transfer pricing records: carelessness for the purposes of section 29

4.30C

4.30C.1

This section applies where—

4.30C.1.a

the situation mentioned in section 29(1) has been brought about by a relevant
trustee, or a person acting on their behalf, as regards a relevant year of
assessment,

4.30C.1.b

the situation relates to the calculation of profits or losses in accordance

4.30C.1.c

the relevant person has failed to comply, in relation to specified relevant
transfer pricing records that relate to the calculation, with either or both
of—

4.30C.1.c.i

section 12B (records to be kept for the purposes of returns), and

4.30C.1.c.ii

an information notice (within the meaning of Schedule 36 to the Finance Act
2008 (information and inspection powers)).

4.30C.2

It is to be presumed for the purposes of section 29 that the situation
mentioned in section 29(1) was brought about carelessly by the relevant
trustee, or the person acting on their behalf, unless—

4.30C.2.a

the situation was brought about deliberately by the relevant trustee, or the
person acting on their behalf, or

4.30C.2.b

the relevant trustee satisfies HMRC or (on an appeal notified to the tribunal)

care to avoid the situation.

4.30C.3

4.30C.3.a

assessment;

4.30C.3.b

“ relevant year of assessment ” means a year of assessment in respect of
which—

4.30C.3.b.i

the trustees of the trust concerned, together with one or more other
enterprises, constitutes an MNE Group within the meaning of the Taxes (Base
Erosion and Profit Shifting) (Country-by-Country Reporting) Regulations 2016 (
S.I. 2016/237 ) (see regulation 2(3) of those Regulations), and

4.30C.3.b.ii

the MNE Group meets the threshold requirement within the meaning of those
Regulations (see regulations 3(2) to (4) of those Regulations);

4.30C.3.c

records are “specified relevant transfer pricing records” if—

4.30C.3.c.i

they are relevant transfer pricing records specified, or of a description
specified, in regulations under section 12B, and

4.30C.3.c.ii

the relevant person is required to keep and preserve those records under that
section.

########## Transfer pricing records: carelessness for the purposes of section 30B

4.30D

4.30D.1

This section applies where—

4.30D.1.a

the situation mentioned in section 30B(1) has been brought about by a person

4.30D.1.b

the situation relates to the calculation of profits or losses in accordance
with Part 4 of TIOPA 2010 (transfer pricing) for the purposes of that period,
and

4.30D.1.c

the relevant person (whether or not P) has failed to comply, in relation to
specified relevant transfer pricing records that relate to the calculation,
with either or both of—

4.30D.1.c.i

section 12B (records to be kept for the purposes of returns), and

4.30D.1.c.ii

an information notice (within the meaning of Schedule 36 to the Finance Act
2008 (information and inspection powers)).

4.30D.2

It is to be presumed for the purposes of section 30B that the situation
mentioned in section 30B(1) was brought about carelessly by P, unless—

4.30D.2.a

the situation was brought about deliberately by P, or

4.30D.2.b

the relevant person satisfies HMRC or (on an appeal notified to the tribunal)
the tribunal that P took reasonable care to avoid the situation.

4.30D.3

For the purposes of this paragraph—

4.30D.3.a

“ relevant period ” means a period in respect of which—

4.30D.3.a.i

the partnership to which the partnership statement relates, together with one
or more other enterprises, constitutes an MNE Group within the meaning of the
Taxes (Base Erosion and Profit Shifting) (Country-by-Country Reporting)
Regulations 2016 ( S.I. 2016/237 ) (see regulation 2(3) of those Regulations),
and

4.30D.3.a.ii

the MNE Group meets the threshold requirement within the meaning of those
Regulations (see regulations 3(2) to (4) of those Regulations);

4.30D.3.b

“ relevant person ” means a person who was required by a notice under section
12AA to make and deliver the return in respect of the relevant period;

4.30D.3.c

records are “specified relevant transfer pricing records” if—

4.30D.3.c.i

they are relevant transfer pricing records specified, or of a description
specified, in regulations under section 12B, and

4.30D.3.c.ii

the relevant person is required to keep and preserve those records under that
section.

############ Errors related to transfer pricing records

Condition E is that the notice is given for the purpose of obtaining any
specified relevant transfer pricing information or documents.

6.2.b.8B

For the purposes of Condition E, information or documents are “specified
relevant transfer pricing information or documents” if—

6.2.b.8B.a

they are relevant transfer pricing records specified, or of a description
specified, in regulations under section 12B of TMA 1970 or paragraph 21 of
Schedule 18 to FA 1998 (duties to keep and preserve records), and

6.2.b.8B.b

the relevant person is required to keep and preserve those records under
either or both of those provisions.

6.2.b.8C

For the purposes of  subsection (8B) , the “ relevant person ” means—

6.2.b.8C.a

in the case of a tax return made in respect of a chargeable period under
section 8A or 12AA of TMA 1970 (trustee’s and partnership returns)—

6.2.b.8C.a.i

the person, or

6.2.b.8C.a.ii

a person who was required by a notice under the section concerned to make and
deliver the return;

6.2.b.8C.b

in any other case, the person.

;

6.3

In Part 6 (special cases), after paragraph 37B insert—

############ Specified relevant transfer pricing documents

6.3.37C

6.3.37C.1

This paragraph applies to an information notice given to a relevant person in
an MNE Group (“ A ”) to the extent that the notice refers to specified
relevant transfer pricing documents.

6.3.37C.2

Paragraph 18 (documents not in person’s possession or power) does not apply in
relation to a specified relevant transfer pricing document that—

6.3.37C.2.a

is not in A’s possession or power, but

6.3.37C.2.b

is in the power or possession of another relevant person in the MNE Group
concerned (“ B ”),

(and accordingly the information notice may require A to produce the
document).

6.3.37C.3

For the purposes of this paragraph—

6.3.37C.3.a

documents are “specified relevant transfer pricing documents” if—

6.3.37C.3.a.i

they are relevant transfer pricing records specified, or of a description
specified, in regulations under section 12B of TMA 1970 or paragraph 21 of
Schedule 18 to FA 1998 (duties to keep and preserve records), and

6.3.37C.3.a.ii

A is required to keep and preserve those records under either or both of those
provisions;

6.3.37C.3.b

“ MNE Group ” has the same meaning as in the Taxes (Base Erosion and Profit
Shifting) (Country-by-Country Reporting) Regulations 2016 ( S.I. 2016/237 )
(see regulation 2(3) of those Regulations);

6.3.37C.3.c

“ relevant person in an MNE Group ” means—

6.3.37C.3.c.i

a company,

6.3.37C.3.c.ii

a trustee of a trust, or

6.3.37C.3.c.iii

a partner in a partnership,

where that company, the trustees or the partnership, together with one or more
other enterprises, constitutes an MNE Group.

##### Commencement

7

Regulations made under—

7.a

paragraph 21 of Schedule 18 to FA 1998 by virtue of the amendments made by
paragraph 1  of this Schedule, or

7.b

section 12B of TMA 1970 by virtue of the amendments made by  paragraph 3  of
this Schedule,

have effect in relation to such accounting periods or tax years beginning on
or after 1 April 2023 as are specified in the regulations.

Categories of alcoholic products: interpretation

Section 44

##### Spirits

1

“ Spirits ” means—

1.a

spirits of any description, and

1.b

any mixture or compound made with spirits (including, subject to the following
provisions of this Schedule, mixtures that also contain other alcoholic
products).

2

The extraction of spirits absorbed in a wooden cask is treated, for the
purposes of this Part, as the production of spirits.

##### Beer

3

“ Beer ” means—

3.a

ale,

3.b

porter,

3.c

stout,

3.d

any other type of beer, and

3.e

any other product which is made or sold as beer or as a substitute for beer.

4

4.1

A qualifying beer-based beverage is treated as beer for the purposes of this
Part.

4.2

“ Beer-based beverage ” means a beverage which is a mixture of beer and any of
the following—

4.2.a

fruit or ginger—

4.2.a.i

cordial,

4.2.a.ii

carbonated water,

4.2.a.iii

juice, or

4.2.a.iv

squash;

4.2.b

lemonade or limeade;

4.2.c

unfermented ginger beer;

4.2.d

any alcoholic product or other alcoholic substance.

4.3

A beer-based beverage is “qualifying” if—

4.3.a

it would, apart from  this paragraph , fall within  paragraph 12  (other
fermented products), and

4.3.b

it is of an alcoholic strength not exceeding 5.5%.

##### Cider

5

“ Cider ” means a product which—

5.a

is obtained from the fermentation of apple juice or pear juice,

5.b

has been produced without the addition, at any time, of—

5.b.i

another alcoholic product, or

5.b.ii

anything, other than a permitted substance, which communicates colour or
flavour,

5.c

satisfies the juice content requirements (see  paragraph 7 ), and

5.d

is of an alcoholic strength of less than 8.5%.

6

In  paragraph 5 , “ permitted substance ” means a substance that—

6.a

appears to the Commissioners to be necessary for the purposes of producing
cider, and

6.b

is specified in a notice published by the Commissioners for the purposes of
this Schedule .

7

7.1

For the purposes of  paragraph 5 , the juice content requirements are
satisfied in relation to a product if—

7.1.a

qualifying fruit juice comprises at least 35% of the volume of the pre-
fermentation mixture for the product, and

7.1.b

the total of—

7.1.b.i

the volume of qualifying fruit juice included in the pre-fermentation mixture,
and

7.1.b.ii

the volume of qualifying fruit juice added after fermentation begins,

comprises at least 35% of the end product.

7.2

“ Qualifying fruit juice ” means apple or pear juice of a gravity of at least
1033 degrees.

7.3

The “gravity” of apple or pear juice in degrees is determined by—

7.3.a

calculating the ratio of the weight of the volume of the juice to the weight
of an equal volume of distilled water (both as at 20°C), and

7.3.b

multiplying that ratio by 1000.

7.4

“ Pre-fermentation mixture ” means the mixture of juice and other ingredients
in which the fermentation (from which the cider is obtained) takes place, as
that mixture exists immediately before the fermentation process begins.

7.5

If the cider consists of a blend of two or more products, each constituting
cider, references in  sub-paragraph (4)  to the pre-fermentation mixture are
to the pre-fermentation mixtures for each of those products taken as a whole.

8

8.1

“ Sparkling cider ” means cider which—

8.1.a

if it is packaged in a closed bottle, either—

8.1.a.i

due to the presence of carbon dioxide, the pressure in the bottle, measured at
a temperature of 20°C, is not less than 3 bars in excess of atmospheric
pressure, or

8.1.a.ii

(regardless of the pressure) the bottle has a mushroom-shaped stopper held in
place by a tie or fastening;

8.1.b

if it is not packaged in a closed bottle, has characteristics similar to those
of cider which (while packaged in a closed bottle) falls within  paragraph (a)
(i) .

8.2

Cider is to be regarded as having been rendered sparkling if—

8.2.a

as a result of aeration, fermentation or any other process, it falls within
sub-paragraph (1) , or

8.2.b

(if not previously rendered sparkling under  paragraph (a) ) it is transferred
into a closed bottle which has, or the stopper of its bottle is exchanged for,
a stopper of the kind mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(a)(ii).

9

Rendering cider sparkling, at any time after the excise duty point in relation
to that cider, is treated for the purposes of this Part as producing sparkling
cider.

10

“ Still cider ” means cider that is not sparkling cider.

##### Wine

11

“ Wine ” means any product obtained from the alcoholic fermentation of fresh
grapes or of the must of fresh grapes (whether or not the product is fortified
with spirits).

##### Other fermented products

12

“ Other fermented product ” means a product which—

12.a

is either—

12.a.i

obtained from the alcoholic fermentation of any substance, or

12.a.ii

obtained by mixing a product obtained from the alcoholic fermentation of any
substance, or anything derived from that product, with anything else; but

12.b

is not beer, cider, wine or spirits.

Penalties for contraventions of alcohol wholesaling provisions

Section 105

##### Liability to penalty

1

A penalty is payable by a person (“ P ”) who contravenes  section 100 (1)  or
103 (1) .

##### Amount of penalty

2

2.1

If the contravention is deliberate and concealed, the amount of the penalty is
the maximum amount (see  paragraph 10 ).

2.2

If the contravention is deliberate but not concealed, the amount of the
penalty is 70% of the maximum amount.

2.3

In any other case, the amount of the penalty is 30% of the maximum amount.

2.4

The contravention is—

2.4.a

“deliberate and concealed” if the contravention is deliberate and P makes
arrangements to conceal the contravention, and

2.4.b

“deliberate but not concealed” if the contravention is deliberate but P does
not make arrangements to conceal the contravention.

##### Reductions for disclosure

3

3.1

Paragraph 4  provides for reductions in penalties under  this Schedule  where
P discloses a contravention.

3.2

P discloses a contravention by—

3.2.a

telling the Commissioners about it,

3.2.b

giving the Commissioners reasonable help in identifying any other
contraventions of  section 100 (1)  or  103 (1)  of which P is aware, and

3.2.c

allowing the Commissioners access to records for the purpose of identifying
such contraventions.

3.3

Disclosure of a contravention—

3.3.a

is “unprompted” if made at a time when P has no reason to believe that the
Commissioners have discovered or are about to discover the contravention, and

3.3.b

otherwise, is “prompted”.

3.4

In relation to disclosure “ quality ” includes timing, nature and extent.

4

4.1

Where P discloses a contravention, the Commissioners must reduce the penalty
to one that reflects the quality of the disclosure.

4.2

If the disclosure is prompted, the penalty may not be reduced below—

4.2.a

in the case of a contravention that is deliberate and concealed, 50% of the
maximum amount,

4.2.b

in the case of a contravention that is deliberate but not concealed, 35% of
the maximum amount, and

4.2.c

in any other case, 20% of the maximum amount.

4.3

If the disclosure is unprompted, the penalty may not be reduced below—

4.3.a

in the case of a contravention that is deliberate and concealed, 30% of the
maximum amount,

4.3.b

in the case of a contravention that is deliberate but not concealed, 20% of
the maximum amount, and

4.3.c

in any other case, 10% of the maximum amount.

##### Special reduction

5

5.1

If the Commissioners think it right because of special circumstances, they may
reduce a penalty under  this Schedule .

5.2

In  sub-paragraph (1)  “ special circumstances ” does not include ability to
pay.

5.3

In  sub-paragraph (1)  the reference to reducing a penalty includes a
reference to—

5.3.a

staying a penalty, and

5.3.b

agreeing a compromise in relation to proceedings for a penalty.

##### Assessment

6

6.1

Where P becomes liable for a penalty under  this Schedule , the Commissioners
must—

6.1.a

assess the penalty,

6.1.b

notify P, and

6.1.c

state in the notice the contravention in respect of which the penalty is
assessed.

6.2

A penalty under  this Schedule  must be paid before the end of the period of
30 days beginning with the day on which notification of the penalty is issued.

6.3

An assessment is to be treated as an amount of duty due from P under this Act
and may be recovered accordingly.

6.4

An assessment of a penalty under  this Schedule  may not be made later than
one year after evidence of facts sufficient in the opinion of the
Commissioners to indicate the contravention comes to their knowledge.

6.5

Two or more contraventions may be treated by the Commissioners as a single
contravention for the purposes of assessing a penalty under  this Schedule .

##### Reasonable excuse

7

7.1

Liability to a penalty does not arise under  this Schedule  in respect of a
contravention which is not deliberate if P satisfies the Commissioners or (on
an appeal made to the appeal tribunal) the tribunal that there is a reasonable
excuse for the contravention.

7.2

For the purposes of  sub-paragraph (1) , where P relies on any other person to
do anything, that is not a reasonable excuse unless P took reasonable care to
avoid the contravention.

##### Companies: officer’s liability

8

8.1

Where a penalty under  this Schedule  is payable by a company in respect of a
contravention which was attributable to an officer of the company, the officer
is liable to pay such portion of the penalty (which may be 100%) as the
Commissioners may specify by written notice to the officer.

8.2

Sub-paragraph (1)  does not allow the Commissioners to recover more than 100%
of a penalty.

8.3

In the application of  sub-paragraph (1)  to a body corporate other than a
limited liability partnership, “ officer ” means—

8.3.a

a director (including a shadow director within the meaning of section 251 of
the Companies Act 2006),

8.3.b

a manager, and

8.3.c

a secretary.

8.4

In the application of  sub-paragraph (1)  to a limited liability partnership,
“ officer ” means a member.

8.5

In the application of  sub-paragraph (1)  in any other case, “ officer ”
means—

8.5.a

a director,

8.5.b

a manager,

8.5.c

a secretary, and

8.5.d

any other person managing or purporting to manage any of the company’s
affairs.

8.6

Where the Commissioners have specified a portion of a penalty in a notice
given to an officer under  sub-paragraph (1) —

8.6.a

paragraph 5  applies to the specified portion as to a penalty,

8.6.b

the officer must pay the specified portion before the end of the period of 30
days beginning with the day on which the notice is given,

8.6.c

sub-paragraphs (3)  to  (5)  of  paragraph 6  apply as if the notice were an
assessment of a penalty, and

8.6.d

paragraph 9  applies as if the officer were liable to a penalty.

8.7

In  this paragraph  “ company ” means any body corporate or unincorporated
association, but does not include a partnership.

##### Double jeopardy

9

P is not liable to a penalty under  this Schedule  in respect of a
contravention in respect of which P has been convicted of an offence.

##### The maximum amount

10

10.1

In  this Schedule , “ the maximum amount ” means £10,000.

10.2

If it appears to the Treasury that there has been a change in the value of
money since the last relevant date, the Treasury may by regulations substitute
for the sum for the time being specified in  sub-paragraph (1)  such other sum
as appears to them to be justified by the change.

10.3

In  sub-paragraph (2) , “ relevant date ” means—

10.3.a

the date on which the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023 is passed, and

10.3.b

each date on which the power conferred by that sub-paragraph has been
exercised.

10.4

Regulations under  this paragraph  do not apply to any contravention which
occurred before the date on which they come into force.

##### Appeal tribunal

11

In  this Schedule  “ appeal tribunal ” has the same meaning as in Chapter 2 of
Part 1 of the FA 1994.

Alcohol duty: reviews and appeals

Section 108

1

1.1

Section 13A(2) of FA 1994 (meaning of “ relevant decision ”) is amended as
follows.

1.2

In paragraph (c), for “section 8, 10, 11 or 36G of the Alcoholic Liquor Duties
Act 1979,” substitute  “ section 52 ,  60 ,  78  or  79  of  Part 2  of the
Finance (No. 2) Act 2023 (alcohol duty),” .

1.3

In paragraph (ea), for sub-paragraphs (i) and (ii) substitute—

1.3.i

regulations under  section 102  of  Part 2  of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023
(alcohol duty), or

1.3.ii

Schedule 12  to that Act;

.

1.4

In paragraph (f), for “paragraph 4(2)(h) of Schedule 2A to the Alcoholic
Liquor Duties Act 1979 (duty stamps)” substitute  “ paragraph 4 (2) (h)  of
Schedule 12  to the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023 (alcohol duty: duty stamps)” .

2

In Schedule 5 to FA 1994 (decisions subject to review and appeal), for
paragraph 3 (and the heading immediately preceding it) substitute—

######## Part 2 of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023 (alcohol duty)

2.3

2.3.1

The following decisions under or for the purposes of  Part 2  of the Finance
(No. 2) Act 2023 (alcohol duty)—

2.3.1.a

any decision as to whether or not any duty is to be remitted or repaid under
section 73  (research and experiments) or  74  (spoilt alcoholic products) as
to the conditions subject to which the duty is to be remitted or repaid;

2.3.1.b

any decision—

2.3.1.b.i

on a claim under  section 75  for repayment of duty (alcoholic ingredients
relief), or

2.3.1.b.ii

as to whether or not to remit duty under that section;

2.3.1.c

any decision for the purposes of  section 76  (imported medical articles) or
section 78  (authorised use for certain purposes) as to whether or not to
recognise any article as used for medical purposes;

2.3.1.d

any decision for the purposes of  section 78  (authorised use for certain
purposes)—

2.3.1.d.i

as to the use to which any article is or is to be put, or as to the purposes
for which it is or is to be used,

2.3.1.d.ii

as to whether or not permission or authorisation for any person to receive, or
for the delivery of, any spirits without payment of duty is to be granted or
withdrawn, or

2.3.1.d.iii

as to the conditions subject to which the permission or authorisation is
granted;

2.3.1.e

any decision for the purposes of  section 79  (imported goods not for human
consumption) as to whether or not any goods are for human consumption;

2.3.1.f

any decision for the purposes of  section 82  (approval requirement:
producers) or  83  (supplementary provision about approvals)—

2.3.1.f.i

as to whether or not, and in respect of which alcoholic products, premises or
activities, an approval is given,

2.3.1.f.ii

the period for which, or conditions subject to which, an approval is given,

2.3.1.f.iii

as to the revocation or variation of an approval, or

2.3.1.f.iv

as to whether a person is exempt from the approval requirement;

2.3.1.g

any decision as to the application of an exemption under  section 86  (mixing
alcoholic products);

2.3.1.h

any decision as to whether or not a licence for the purposes of  section 91
(licence to manufacture and deal wholesale in denatured alcohol) is to be
granted to a person, or as to the revocation or suspension of a licence for
the purposes of that section;

2.3.1.i

any decision for the purposes of any provision of  Chapter 7  (wholesaling of
controlled alcoholic products) as to whether or not, and in which respects, a
person is to be, or to continue to be, approved and registered or as to the
conditions or restrictions subject to which a person is to be approved and
registered;

2.3.1.j

any decision for the purposes of  section 111  as to whether or not any
drawback is to be set against an amount chargeable in respect of alcohol duty
or as to the conditions subject to which drawback is set against that amount.

2.3.2

Any decision which—

2.3.2.a

is made under or for the purposes of any regulations under  section 88
(alcoholic products regulations) of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023, and

2.3.2.b

is a decision as to whether or not a person is to be required to give security
for the fulfilment of an obligation or as to the form or amount of, or the
conditions of, the security.

2.3.3

Any decision which is made under or for the purposes of any regulations under
section 90  (denatured alcohol) or  section 92  (regulations relating to
denatured alcohol) of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023 and is a decision—

2.3.3.a

as to whether or not any process is to be, or to continue to be, approved for
any purposes;

2.3.3.b

as to the conditions subject to which the approval is given;

2.3.3.c

as to the revocation or variation of an approval;

2.3.3.d

as to whether or not a person is to be required to give security for the
fulfilment of an obligation or as to the form or amount of, or the conditions
of, the security.

2.3.4

Any decision which—

2.3.4.a

is made under paragraph 1 of Schedule 3 to the Finance Act 2001, and

2.3.4.b

relates to  Part 2  of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023.

Alcohol duty: duty stamps

Section 112

##### Retail containers to be stamped

1

1.1

Retail containers of alcoholic products to which  this Schedule  applies are
to be stamped—

1.1.a

in such cases and circumstances, and with a duty stamp of such a type, as may
be prescribed; but

1.1.b

subject to such exceptions as may be prescribed.

1.2

In  this Schedule  “ retail container ”, in relation to an alcoholic product,
means a container—

1.2.a

of a capacity of 35 centilitres or more, and

1.2.b

in which, or from which, the alcoholic product is intended to be sold by
retail.

1.3

This Schedule  applies to alcoholic products that are—

1.3.a

spirits, wine or other fermented products, and

1.3.b

of an alcoholic strength of at least 30%.

1.4

For the purposes of  this Schedule  a retail container is “stamped” if—

1.4.a

it carries a type A stamp or a label which incorporates a type B stamp, and

1.4.b

the stamp or label mentioned in  paragraph (a)  has been affixed to the
container in a way that complies with the requirements of regulations under
this Schedule .

1.5

In  this Schedule  “ duty stamp ” means any of the following—

1.5.a

a document (a “type A stamp”) issued by or on behalf of the Commissioners
which—

1.5.a.i

is designed to be affixed to a retail container of an alcoholic product, and

1.5.a.ii

indicates that the appropriate duty, or an amount representing some or all of
the appropriate duty, has been (or is to be) paid;

1.5.b

a part of a label for a retail container of an alcoholic product (a “type B
stamp”) which—

1.5.b.i

is incorporated in the label under the authority of the Commissioners, and

1.5.b.ii

indicates that the appropriate duty, or an amount representing some or all of
the appropriate duty, has been (or is to be) paid.

1.6

In  sub-paragraph (5)  “ the appropriate duty ” means the duty chargeable on
the quantity and description of the alcoholic product contained, or to be
contained, in the retail container to which the stamp, or the label
incorporating the stamp, is, or is to be, affixed.

##### Power to alter alcoholic products, and capacity of containers, to which 

2

2.1

The Treasury may by regulations amend  paragraph 1 (2) (a)  for the purpose of
varying the capacity from time to time specified in that provision.

2.2

The Treasury may by regulations amend  paragraph 1 (3)  so that  this Schedule
—

2.2.a

applies to any description of alcoholic product to which it does not apply, or

2.2.b

ceases to apply to any description of alcoholic product to which it does
apply.

##### Acquisition of, and payment for, duty stamps

3

3.1

The Commissioners may by regulations make provision as to the terms and
conditions on which a person may obtain—

3.1.a

a type A stamp,

3.1.b

authority to incorporate in a label a type B stamp,

3.1.c

authority to obtain a label incorporating a type B stamp (a “type B label”),

3.1.d

authority to affix a type B label to a retail container of an alcoholic
product.

3.2

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (1)  may in particular make provision for or
in connection with—

3.2.a

requiring a person in prescribed cases or circumstances to pay, or agree to
pay, the prescribed amount to the Commissioners or to a person authorised by
the Commissioners for this purpose;

3.2.b

requiring a person in prescribed cases or circumstances to provide to the
Commissioners such security as they may require in respect of payment of the
appropriate duty.

3.3

An amount prescribed for the purposes of  sub-paragraph (2) (a)  must not
exceed the aggregate of—

3.3.a

an amount representing the appropriate duty, and

3.3.b

in the case of a type A stamp, the cost of issuing the stamp.

3.4

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (1)  may also in particular make provision
for or in connection with requiring or enabling the Commissioners to bear, in
prescribed circumstances, in the case of a type B stamp, all or part of so
much of the cost of producing the label as is attributable to the
incorporation in it of the stamp.

3.5

The whole of an amount payable for a duty stamp shall be treated for the
purposes of the customs and excise Acts as an amount due by way of excise
duty.

3.6

In  this paragraph  “ the appropriate duty ” means the duty chargeable on the
quantity and description of alcoholic product contained, or to be contained,
in the retail container to which the stamp, or the label incorporating the
stamp, is to be affixed.

##### Regulations

4

4.1

The Commissioners may by regulations make provision about matters relating to
duty stamps.

4.2

The regulations may, in particular, make provision about—

4.2.a

the times at which a retail container must bear a duty stamp;

4.2.b

the type of duty stamp (see  paragraph 1 (5) ) with which a retail container
is to be stamped in any particular case or circumstances;

4.2.c

the design and appearance of a duty stamp (including the production of a type
B label);

4.2.d

the information that is to appear on a duty stamp;

4.2.e

the cost of issuing a type A stamp for the purposes of  paragraph 3 (3) (b) ;

4.2.f

the procedure for obtaining—

4.2.f.i

a type A stamp,

4.2.f.ii

authority to incorporate in a label a type B stamp,

4.2.f.iii

authority to obtain a type B label,

4.2.f.iv

authority to affix a type B label to a retail container of an alcoholic
product,

(including provision setting periods of notice);

4.2.g

where on the container a type A stamp, or a type B label, is to be affixed;

4.2.h

repayment of, or credit for, in prescribed circumstances and subject to such
conditions as may be prescribed, all or part of a payment made under or by
reason of  this Schedule  to the Commissioners or to a person authorised by
the Commissioners;

4.2.i

liability to forfeiture in prescribed circumstances of some or all of a
payment made, or security provided, under or by reason of  this Schedule  to
the Commissioners or to a person authorised by the Commissioners.

4.3

The regulations may also, in particular, make provision for or in connection
with preventing a type A stamp, or a type B label, from being used by a person
other than—

4.3.a

in the case of a type A stamp, the person to or for whom the stamp was issued
or a person authorised by that person to affix the stamp to a retail container
of an alcoholic product;

4.3.b

in the case of a type B stamp, the person to or for whom authority to obtain
the type B label, or to affix that label to a retail container of an alcoholic
product, was given by the Commissioners.

4.4

The regulations may also, in particular, make provision—

4.4.a

for or in connection with requiring a person (“ P ”) who is not established,
and does not have any fixed establishment, in the United Kingdom, in
prescribed circumstances, to appoint another person (a “duty stamps
representative”) to act on P’s behalf in relation to duty stamps, and

4.4.b

as to the rights, obligations or liabilities of duty stamps representatives.

4.5

The Commissioners may, with a view to the protection of the revenue, make
regulations for securing and collecting duty payable in accordance with  this
Schedule .

##### Offences of possession, sale etc of unstamped containers

5

5.1

Except in such cases as may be prescribed, it is an offence for a person to—

5.1.a

possess, transport or display, or

5.1.b

sell, offer for sale or otherwise deal in,

unstamped retail containers containing alcoholic products to which  this
Schedule  applies.

5.2

It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under  this paragraph  to
prove that the retail containers in question were not required to be stamped.

5.3

A person who commits an offence under  this paragraph  is liable—

5.3.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to a fine not exceeding £20,000;

5.3.b

on summary conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland, to a fine not exceeding
level 5 on the standard scale.

5.4

A retail container in relation to which an offence under  this paragraph  is
committed is liable to forfeiture (together with its contents).

##### Offence of using premises for sale of alcoholic products in or from unstamped containers

6

6.1

It is an offence for a manager of premises to cause or permit the premises to
be used for the sale of alcoholic products, to which  this Schedule  applies,
in or from an unstamped retail container.

6.2

It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under this section to
prove that the retail container in question was not required to be stamped.

6.3

A person who commits an offence under  this paragraph  is liable—

6.3.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to a fine not exceeding £20,000;

6.3.b

on summary conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland, to a fine not exceeding
level 5 on the standard scale.

6.4

Where an offence under  this paragraph  is committed, all unstamped retail
containers of alcoholic products on the premises at the time of the offence
are liable to forfeiture (together with their contents).

6.5

For the purposes of  this Schedule , a person is a “manager” of premises if
the person—

6.5.a

is entitled to control their use,

6.5.b

is entrusted with their management, or

6.5.c

is in charge of them.

##### Alcohol sales ban following conviction for an offence under 

7

7.1

A court by or before which a person is convicted of an offence under
paragraph 6  may make an order prohibiting the use of the premises, in respect
of which the offence was committed, for the sale of alcoholic products during
a period specified in the order.

7.2

The period—

7.2.a

begins on the day specified in the order, and

7.2.b

may not exceed 6 months.

7.3

It is an offence for a manager of premises to cause or permit the premises to
be used in breach of an order under  this paragraph .

7.4

A person who commits an offence under  this paragraph  is liable—

7.4.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to a fine not exceeding £20,000;

7.4.b

on summary conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland, to a fine not exceeding
level 5 on the standard scale.

##### Penalty for altering duty stamps

8

8.1

This paragraph  applies where a person, otherwise than in accordance with
regulations under  this Schedule —

8.1.a

alters a type A stamp after it has been issued, or

8.1.b

alters a type B stamp after the label in which it is incorporated has been
produced.

8.2

The alteration is conduct which attracts a penalty under section 9 of FA 1994
(civil penalties).

8.3

The stamp, or the label in which it is incorporated, is liable to forfeiture.

##### Penalty for affixing wrong, altered or forged stamps, or over-labelling

9

9.1

This paragraph  applies where a person affixes to a retail container that is
required to be stamped any of the items mentioned in  sub-paragraphs (2)  to
(5) .

9.2

The first is—

9.2.a

a type A stamp, or

9.2.b

a label incorporating a type B stamp,

if the stamp is not a correct stamp for that container in accordance with
regulations under  this Schedule .

9.3

The second is—

9.3.a

a type A stamp that has been altered, otherwise than in accordance with
regulations under  this Schedule , after it has been issued, or

9.3.b

a label incorporating a type B stamp if the stamp has been altered, otherwise
than in accordance with regulations under  this Schedule , after the label has
been produced.

9.4

The third is an item that purports to be (but is not)—

9.4.a

a type A stamp, or

9.4.b

a label incorporating a type B stamp.

9.5

The fourth is any label or other item affixed in such a way as to cover up all
or part of—

9.5.a

a type A stamp affixed to the container, or

9.5.b

a type B stamp incorporated in a label affixed to the container,

except where the label or other item is so affixed in accordance with
regulations under  this Schedule .

9.6

The person’s conduct attracts a penalty under section 9 of FA 1994 (civil
penalties).

9.7

The retail container is liable to forfeiture (together with its contents).

##### Penalty for failing to comply with regulations

10

10.1

If a person fails to comply with a requirement imposed by or under regulations
under  this Schedule —

10.1.a

the person’s conduct attracts a penalty under section 9 of FA 1994;

10.1.b

any article in respect of which the person fails to comply with the
requirement is liable to forfeiture (including, in the case of a container,
its contents).

10.2

Regulations under  this Schedule  may make provision as to the amount by
reference to which the penalty under  sub-paragraph (1) (a)  is to be
calculated.

##### Forfeiture of forged, altered or stolen duty stamps

11

11.1

The following items are liable to forfeiture.

11.2

The first is an item that purports to be (but is not)—

11.2.a

a type A stamp, or

11.2.b

a label incorporating a type B stamp.

11.3

The second is—

11.3.a

a type A stamp that has been altered, otherwise than in accordance with
regulations under  this Schedule , after it has been issued, or

11.3.b

a label incorporating a type B stamp if the stamp has been altered, otherwise
than in accordance with regulations under  this Schedule , after the label has
been produced.

11.4

The third is—

11.4.a

a type A stamp, or

11.4.b

a label incorporating a type B stamp,

that is in a person’s possession unlawfully.

##### Interpretation

12

In  this Schedule —

“ duty stamp ” has the meaning given by  paragraph 1 (5) ; “ prescribed ”
means prescribed in regulations made by the Commissioners; “ retail container
” has the meaning given by  paragraph 1 (2) ; “ stamped ” and “unstamped” are
to be read in accordance with  paragraph 1 (4) ; “ type A stamp ” has the
meaning given by  paragraph 1 (5) (a) ; “ type B stamp ” has the meaning given
by  paragraph 1 (5) (b) .

Administration of multinational top-up tax

Section 125

##### Overview

1

1.1

The Commissioners for His Majesty’s Revenue and Customs are responsible for
the collection and management of multinational top-up tax.

1.2

This Schedule —

1.2.a

contains provision to enable HMRC to determine when a person is chargeable to
multinational top-up tax for an accounting period;

1.2.b

contains requirements to provide information to HMRC for the purposes of
multinational top-up and taxes under the law of other territories that are
equivalent to multinational top-up tax;

1.2.c

allows for the assessment of amounts of multinational top-up tax;

1.2.d

sets out associated administrative provisions;

1.2.e

makes consequential and other amendments to other enactments.

1.3

This Schedule  makes provision about a “filing member” of a multinational
group (see Part  2 ) and contains provision requiring such a member to—

1.3.a

register with HMRC (see Part  3 );

1.3.b

submit an information return to HMRC (see Part  4 );

1.3.c

submit a self-assessment return to HMRC (see Part  5 );

1.3.d

keep and preserve records (see Part  9 ).

1.4

Part 10  of  this Schedule  makes provision for when and how payment of
multinational top-up tax payable is to be made.

1.5

This Schedule  makes provision for—

1.5.a

penalties (see Part  11 );

1.5.b

appeals and claims for repayment of overpaid tax (see Part  12 ).

##### Meaning of “filing member”

2

2.1

The filing member of a multinational group is the ultimate parent of that
group, unless a nomination under sub-paragraph  (2)  is in force.

2.2

The nomination referred to in  sub-paragraph (1)  is a nomination by the
ultimate parent of the group that another person should act as the filing
member.

2.3

The ultimate parent may only nominate a person if—

2.3.a

the person is a member of the group, and

2.3.b

the person is a company.

2.4

If the ultimate parent nominates a person under sub-paragraph  (2) , they
must—

2.4.a

nominate the same person as the filing member for the purposes of  Schedule 18
;

2.4.b

if the nomination ceases to be in force, revoke the nomination referred to in
paragraph  (a) ;

2.4.c

if the nomination referred to in paragraph  (a)  ceases to be in force, revoke
the nomination.

2.5

The ultimate parent must provide the person nominated with everything the
person may reasonably require in order to comply with the obligations of a
filing member under  this Schedule .

2.6

While a nomination under  sub-paragraph (2)  is in force, the filing member of
a multinational group is the person nominated.

2.7

A nomination is in force from the time it is made until any of the following
events occurs—

2.7.a

the ultimate parent nominates another person;

2.7.b

the person nominated ceases to be a member of the group;

2.7.c

the person nominated ceases to be a company;

2.7.d

the ultimate parent revokes the nomination;

2.7.e

an officer of Revenue and Customs revokes the nomination.

2.8

An officer of Revenue and Customs may revoke a nomination if the officer
considers that—

2.8.a

the ultimate parent is not complying with its obligation under sub-paragraph
(5) , or

2.8.b

the person nominated is not complying with the obligations of a filing member
under  this Schedule .

2.9

An officer of Revenue and Customs revokes a nomination by notifying the
ultimate parent and the nominated person of the revocation.

2.10

The revocation has effect when the notification is issued.

2.11

Any nomination, or revocation of a nomination, must be in writing.

2.12

Paragraph 3  makes provision for circumstances in which the ultimate parent is
the filing entity but is not a company.

2.13

Paragraph 4  makes specific provision for a multinational group that is part
of a multi-parent group.

2.14

Paragraph 5  makes provision for the effect of the filing member of a
multinational group changing.

3

3.1

This paragraph  applies where—

3.1.a

the filing member of a multinational group is its ultimate parent, and

3.1.b

the ultimate parent is not a company.

3.2

The obligations of the filing member under  this Schedule  may be met by—

3.2.a

in the case of a partnership other than a limited partnership  ..., any
partner;

3.2.b

in the case of a limited partnership, any general partner;

3.2.c

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

3.2.d

in the case of a trust, any trustee;

3.2.e

in the case of any other arrangement, any person responsible for preparing the
separate financial accounts.

3.3

In this Schedule—

3.3.a

“ limited partnership ” includes an entity established under the law of a
territory outside the United Kingdom that is equivalent to a limited
partnership, and

3.3.b

“ general partner ” includes a partner of such an entity that corresponds to a
general partner.

3.4

See also section 232A, which contains provision about the continuity of
partnerships which is relevant to this paragraph.

3.5

Where an obligation of a partnership may be met by one of its partners and the
partnership does not comply with that obligation—

3.5.a

an officer of Revenue and Customs may by notice require any such partner to
meet the obligation, and

3.5.b

that partner is to be treated for that purpose as the filing member (and
accordingly may be subject to any penalty for a failure to comply).

4

4.1

The obligations of a filing member of a multinational group that is part of a
multi-parent group may be met by the filing member of any of the groups that
are part of that multi-parent group, subject to  sub-paragraph (2) .

4.2

The obligations of the filing member may not be met by a person nominated
under  paragraph 2 (2)  unless the ultimate parent of each group forming the
multi-parent group has authorised the nomination.

4.3

Any authorisation must be in writing.

5

5.1

This paragraph  applies if at any time (“ the relevant time ”) a person (“the
new filing member”) becomes the filing member of a multinational group in
place of another person ( “the old filing member” ).

5.2

The obligations and liabilities of the new filing member under  this Schedule
include any obligations and liabilities the old filing member had under  this
Schedule .

5.3

Anything done as the filing member of the group by or in relation to the old
filing member, before the relevant time, is treated as having been done by or
in relation to the new filing member.

5.4

Accordingly, a penalty may be imposed on the new filing member in respect of
anything done before the relevant time if, at that time, a penalty could have
been imposed on the old filing member in respect of the thing done.

5.5

Anything done by HMRC in relation to the old filing member under  this
Schedule , before the end of the day the change is notified, is treated for
all purposes under  this Schedule  as done in relation to the new filing
member.

5.6

Anything that, at any time during the period beginning with the relevant time
and ending with the day the change is notified, is in the process of being
done under  this Schedule  in relation to the old filing member may be
continued in relation to the new filing member.

5.7

Accordingly, any reference in an enactment or other instrument to the filing
member of the group is to be read, so far as necessary for the purposes of
giving effect to any of  sub-paragraphs (2)  to  (6) , as being or including a
reference to the new filing member.

5.8

In  this paragraph —

5.8.a

any reference to an act includes an omission;

5.8.b

any reference to the day the change is notified is to the day on which an
officer of Revenue and Customs receives notification that the new filing
member has become the filing member of the group.

5.9

Nothing in  this paragraph —

5.9.a

prevents HMRC or anyone else, after the relevant time, from imposing a
penalty, exercising any other power, or doing anything else, in relation to
the old filing member in respect of anything done before the relevant time, or

5.9.b

affects the validity of anything done before the relevant time.

##### Registration

6

6.1

The filing member of a multinational group must register with HMRC if the
group becomes a qualifying multinational group.

6.1A

The reference to a multinational group in sub-paragraph (1) does not include a
group exclusively comprised of excluded entities (who are only regarded as
members of the group for certain purposes in accordance with section 127(2)).

6.2

For the purposes of sub-paragraph  (1) , a multinational group becomes a
qualifying multinational group on the first day of the first accounting period
it is a qualifying multinational group (the  “trigger day” ).

6.3

A filing member registers with HMRC by providing specified information to
HMRC.

6.4

The specified information is—

6.4.a

the name of the filing member;

6.4.b

the name of the ultimate parent (if different to the filing member);

6.4.c

the date of the trigger day;

6.4.d

the date on which the accounting period in which the trigger day occurs will
end or has ended;

6.4.e

any other information that may be specified in a notice published by HMRC.

6.5

The information must be provided in the way specified in a notice published by
HMRC.

6.6

The information must be provided by the end of the period of six months
beginning with the day after the accounting period in which the trigger day
occurs ends.

6.7

In this Schedule, a “ registered group ” means a multinational group that is
registered under this paragraph.

6.8

A multinational group is registered under this paragraph if—

6.8.a

the filing member of the group has registered under this paragraph, and

6.8.b

a notice of de-registration is not in force in relation to the registration
(see paragraph  7 ).

6.9

Paragraphs 8  and  9  provide further notification requirements in relation to
a registered group.

7

7.1

This paragraph applies where the filing member of a multinational group has
registered under paragraph  6 .

7.2

An officer of Revenue and Customs may issue the filing member with a notice of
de-registration in relation to the registration.

7.3

The effect of an officer issuing a notice of de-registration is that,
beginning with the effective date, the registration to which the notice
relates is not to be treated as a registration under paragraph  6 .

7.4

“The effective date” is a date specified in or determined by reference to the
notice as the date on which the notice takes effect.

7.5

But a notice of de-registration does not affect the validity of a registration
for the purposes of any obligation arising before the effective date.

7.6

An officer or Revenue and Customs may issue a notice of de-registration only
if—

7.6.a

the filing member has applied for such a notice, and

7.6.b

it appears to the officer that the group will not be a qualifying
multinational group for any accounting period beginning with the period in
which the effective date falls.

8

8.1

This paragraph  applies where the filing member of a registered group changes.

8.2

The new filing member must notify HMRC of the change before the end of the
period of 6 months beginning with the day the change occurs.

8.3

But, if the change occurs before the end of the period referred to in
paragraph  6 (6) , the new filing member may notify HMRC of the change at any
time before the end of that period even if later than the end of the period in
sub-paragraph  (2) .

8.4

The notification must be given in the way specified in a notice published by
HMRC.

9

9.1

The filing member of a registered group must notify HMRC of any other change
to the information provided under  paragraph 6 .

9.2

The notification must be given before the end of the period of 6 months
beginning with the day on which the change occurs.

9.3

But, if the change occurs before the end of the period referred to in
paragraph  6 (6) , the filing member may notify HMRC of the change at any time
before the end of that period even if later than the end of the period in sub-
paragraph  (2) .

9.4

The notification must be given in the way specified in a notice published by
HMRC.

##### Information returns

10

10.1

The filing member of a registered group must submit an information return to
HMRC for each accounting period in which the group is a qualifying
multinational group, unless sub-paragraph  (4)  applies.

10.2

An “information return” is a return containing the following information—

10.2.a

identification of the members of the group;

10.2.b

information on the overall corporate structure of the group;

10.2.c

information relevant to the determination of effective tax rates, top-up
amounts or allocation of top-up amounts;

10.2.d

such other information specified in a notice published by HMRC as HMRC may
consider relevant to the sharing of information between Pillar Two territories
in connection with the Pillar Two rules.

10.3

HMRC may specify in a notice the particular items of information to be
submitted as part of an information return.

10.4

This sub-paragraph applies if an information return has been submitted for
that period to another qualifying authority.

10.5

A “qualifying authority” is an authority outside the United Kingdom with which
HMRC has an agreement under which the authority will share the information
contained in information returns submitted to that authority with HMRC.

10.6

If  sub-paragraph (4)  applies, the filing member must notify HMRC (an
“overseas return notification”).

10.7

An information return or overseas return notification must be submitted in the
way specified in a notice published by HMRC.

10.8

HMRC may specify in a notice that other information is to be provided together
with an overseas return notification.

10.9

An information return or overseas return notification must be submitted by the
end of the period of 15 months beginning with the day after the end of the
accounting period in respect of which the return or notification is being
submitted.

10.10

But the longer period in sub-paragraph  (11)  applies if the return or
notification is being submitted in respect of the first accounting period in
relation to which the group is a registered group.

10.11

Where this sub-paragraph applies, the information return or overseas return
notification must be submitted by the end of the period of 18 months beginning
with the day after the end of the accounting period.

11

11.1

The filing member may amend a return submitted under paragraph  10  by notice
to HMRC.

11.2

The filing member may further amend a return previously amended by further
notice to HMRC.

11.3

No amendment may be made after the end of the period of 12 months beginning
with the day after the latest date by which the return or notification was
required to be submitted under paragraph  10 .

11.4

An amendment must be submitted in the way specified in a notice published by
HMRC.

12

HMRC may take into account an information return in performing any of its
functions.

##### Self-assessment returns

13

13.1

The filing member of a registered group must submit a self-assessment return
to HMRC for each accounting period, unless  sub-paragraph (3)  applies.

13.2

A “self-assessment return” is a return containing—

13.2.a

an assessment by the filing member as to—

13.2.a.i

which members of the group are chargeable to multinational top-up tax, and

13.2.a.ii

the amount of multinational top-up tax is chargeable to each such member, and

13.2.b

such other information as may be specified in a notice published by HMRC.

13.3

This sub-paragraph applies if—

13.3.a

the conditions in sub-paragraph  (5)  are met in relation to the group for the
accounting period,

13.3.b

the filing member has submitted a below-threshold notification to HMRC, and

13.3.c

the filing member has not withdrawn the below-threshold notification.

13.4

A “below-threshold notification” is a notification that the filing member—

13.4.a

considers that the conditions in sub-paragraph  (5)  are met for an accounting
period, and

13.4.b

does not expect that the conditions will cease to be met for that accounting
period or any subsequent accounting period.

13.5

The conditions are that—

13.5.a

the group was not a qualifying multinational group in the accounting period,
and

13.5.b

the group is unlikely to be a qualifying multinational group in the next two
accounting periods.

13.6

A self-assessment return or below-threshold notification must be submitted in
the way specified in a notice published by HMRC.

13.7

HMRC may specify in a notice that other information is to be provided together
with a below-threshold notification.

13.8

A self-assessment return or below-threshold notification must be submitted by
the end of the period of 15 months beginning with the day after the end of the
accounting period in respect of which the return or notification is being
submitted.

13.9

But the longer period in sub-paragraph  (10)  applies if a self-assessment
return is being submitted in respect of the first accounting period in
relation to which the group is a registered group.

13.10

Where this sub-paragraph applies, the self-assessment return must be submitted
by the end of the period of 18 months beginning with the day after the end of
the accounting period.

14

14.1

The filing member may amend a return submitted under  paragraph 13  by notice
to HMRC.

14.2

The filing member may further amend a return previously amended by further
notice to HMRC.

14.3

No amendment may be made after the end of the period of 12 months beginning
with the day after the latest date by which the return or notification was
required to be submitted under  paragraph 13 .

14.4

An amendment must be submitted in the way specified in a notice published by
HMRC.

##### Enquiries into a self-assessment return

15

15.1

This Part  of  this Schedule  applies if the filing member of a multinational
group has submitted a self-assessment return under  paragraph 13  for an
accounting period.

15.2

In  this Part  “ return ” means a self-assessment return (including as amended
under  paragraph 14 ).

16

16.1

An officer of Revenue and Customs may enquire into the return if, within the
time allowed, the officer gives notice to the filing member of the officer's
intention to do so.

16.2

The time allowed is—

16.2.a

if the return was submitted on or before the submission date, up to the end of
the period of 12 months after the submission date;

16.2.b

if the return was submitted after the submission date, up to and including the
quarter day next following the first anniversary of the day on which the
return was delivered;

16.2.c

if the return is amended under  paragraph 14 , up to and including the quarter
day next following the first anniversary of the day on which the return was
amended.

16.3

The submission date is the day ending the period for submission of the return
referred to in  paragraph 13 (8)  (or the longer period referred to in
paragraph  13 (10)  where applicable).

16.4

The quarter days are 31 January, 30 April, 31 July and 31 October.

16.5

A notice under  this paragraph  is referred to in  this Part  of  this
Schedule  as a “notice of enquiry”.

16.6

A return that has been the subject of one notice of enquiry may not be the
subject of another, except one given in consequence of an amendment of the
return.

17

17.1

An enquiry may extend to anything contained in the return, or required to be
contained in the return, including anything that relates—

17.1.a

to the question of whether multinational top-up tax is chargeable in respect
of the accounting period, or

17.1.b

to the amount of tax so chargeable.

17.2

But, where the notice of enquiry is given in consequence of an amendment of a
return—

17.2.a

at a time when it is no longer possible to give a notice of enquiry under
paragraph 16 (2) (a)  or  (b) ,

17.2.b

after a partial closure notice (see paragraph  22 (1) ) has been issued in
relation to the matters to which the amendment relates or which are affected
by the amendment, or

17.2.c

after an enquiry into a return has been completed,

the enquiry into the return is limited to matters to which the amendment
relates or that are affected by the amendment.

18

18.1

For the purposes of  this Part  an enquiry is in progress into a return for
the whole of the period—

18.1.a

beginning with the day on which notice of enquiry is given in relation to that
return, and

18.1.b

ending with the day on which the enquiry is completed.

18.2

The enquiry is completed on the day a final closure notice is given (see
paragraph  22 (2) ).

19

19.1

If at a time when an enquiry is in progress into a return an officer of
Revenue and Customs forms the opinion—

19.1.a

that an amount stated in the return as the amount of multinational top-up tax
payable by a member of the group is insufficient, and

19.1.b

that unless the assessment in the return is immediately amended there is
likely to be a loss of tax to the Crown,

the officer may by notice in writing to the filing member amend the assessment
to make good the deficiency.

19.2

In the case of an enquiry that under  paragraph 17 (2)  is limited to matters
arising from an amendment of the return,  sub-paragraph (1)  applies only so
far as the deficiency is attributable to the amendment.

19.3

In the case of an enquiry in relation to which one or more partial closure
notices have been given, sub-paragraph  (1)  applies only so far as the
deficiency is attributable to matters not addressed by those notices.

20

20.1

This paragraph  applies if a return is amended at a time when an enquiry is in
progress into the return.

20.2

The amendment does not restrict the scope of the enquiry but may be taken into
account (together with any matters arising) in the enquiry (whether or not the
amendment takes effect under sub-paragraph  (4) ).

20.3

Sub-paragraph  (4)  applies where the amendment is made otherwise than under
paragraph  19 .

20.4

So far as the amendment affects the amount stated in the return as the amount
of tax payable, the amendment does not take effect, in relation to any matter
to which it relates or which is affected by it, while the enquiry is in
progress, except to the extent that—

20.4.a

a partial closure notice has been given in relation to a matter to which the
amendment relates or which is affected by it, and

20.4.b

the notice states that the amendment is to take effect.

20.5

The final closure notice—

20.5.a

must state whether and to what extent an amendment whose effect is deferred
under sub-paragraph  (4)  is to take effect;

20.5.b

may state that an amendment made under paragraph  19 , and whose effect is not
terminated or amended by a partial closure notice, is to cease to have effect
or is to be amended as specified in the notice.

21

21.1

At any time when an enquiry is in progress into a return any question arising
in connection with the subject-matter of the enquiry may be referred to the
tribunal for determination.

21.2

Notice of the referral must be given to the tribunal jointly by the filing
member and an officer of Revenue and Customs.

21.3

More than one notice of referral may be given in relation to an enquiry.

21.4

An officer of Revenue and Customs or the filing member may withdraw a notice
of referral.

21.5

The effect of the notice being withdrawn is that the questions referred are
not (unless they have already been finally determined) to be finally
determined by the tribunal.

21.6

While proceedings on a referral are in progress in relation to an enquiry—

21.6.a

no closure notice may be given in relation to the enquiry, and

21.6.b

no application may be made for a direction to give such a notice.

21.7

Proceedings are in progress where—

21.7.a

notice of referral has been given,

21.7.b

the notice has not been withdrawn, and

21.7.c

the questions referred have not been finally determined.

21.8

In  this paragraph , a question referred is finally determined when—

21.8.a

it has been determined by the tribunal, and

21.8.b

there is no further possibility of the determination being varied or set aside
(disregarding any power to grant permission to appeal out of time).

21.9

The determination of a question referred to the tribunal is binding on the
parties to the referral in the same way, and to the same extent, as a decision
on a preliminary issue in an appeal under Part  12  of  this Schedule .

21.10

The determination must be taken into account by an officer of Revenue and
Customs—

21.10.a

in reaching the officer's conclusions on the enquiry, and

21.10.b

in formulating any amendments of the return required to give effect to those
conclusions.

21.11

The question determined may not be reopened on an appeal under  Part 12  of
this Schedule , except to the extent that it could be reopened if it had been
determined as a preliminary issue in that appeal.

22

22.1

Any matter to which an enquiry into a return relates is completed by an
officer of Revenue and Customs giving the filing member a partial closure
notice.

22.2

An enquiry into a return is completed by an officer of Revenue and Customs
giving the filing member a final closure notice.

22.3

In this Part of this Schedule, “ closure notice ” means a partial closure
notice or a final closure notice.

22.4

A closure notice is a notice stating—

22.4.a

that the enquiry, or the enquiry in so far as it relates to a particular
matter, is complete;

22.4.b

the conclusion reached in the enquiry.

22.5

The conclusion must be one of the following—

22.5.a

that no amendment of the return is required, or

22.5.b

that the amendments of the return specified in the notice are to be made.

22.6

A closure notice takes effect when it is given to the filing member.

22.7

The officer—

22.7.a

must provide additional information together with the notice as to the basis
for the conclusion;

22.7.b

may provide such other information as the officer thinks fit.

22.8

A final closure notice may not, in relation to a matter to which a partial
closure notice relates, state a different conclusion in respect of that matter
to that stated in the partial closure notice.

23

23.1

The filing member may apply to the tribunal for a direction that an officer of
Revenue and Customs give a closure notice within a specified period.

23.2

The tribunal hearing the application must give a direction unless satisfied
that HMRC has reasonable grounds for not giving a closure notice within a
specified period.

23.3

An application under  this paragraph  is to be treated as an appeal under
Part 12  of  this Schedule .

##### Determinations where self-assessment return not submitted

24

This Part  of  this Schedule  applies if the filing member of a multinational
group has not submitted a self-assessment return under  paragraph 13  for an
accounting period.

25

25.1

An officer of Revenue and Customs may make a determination if—

25.1.a

the group is not a registered group and the officer has reasonable grounds to
believe the group should be, or

25.1.b

the officer has reasonable grounds to believe the filing member should have
submitted a self-assessment return.

25.2

A “determination” is a determination by the officer to the best of the
officer’s knowledge and belief as to the total amount of tax payable by a
member of the group for the accounting period.

25.3

The officer must give notice of the determination to the filing member.

25.4

The notice must state the date on which it was issued.

25.5

No determination may be made—

25.5.a

on or before the last date on which the return was required to be submitted or
would have been so required had the group been a registered group;

25.5.b

more than 3 years after that date.

26

26.1

If, after a determination has been made—

26.1.a

a self-assessment return is submitted for the accounting period, and

26.1.b

an information return or overseas return notification has been submitted for
that period,

the assessment in the self-assessment return supersedes the assessment in the
determination.

26.2

Sub-paragraph (1)  does not apply to a self-assessment return delivered after
the later of—

26.2.a

the day 3 years after the day on which the power to make the determination
first became exercisable, and

26.2.b

the day 12 months after the date of the determination.

26.3

Where—

26.3.a

proceedings have begun for the recovery of any tax assessed in a
determination, and

26.3.b

before the proceedings are concluded the determination is superseded under
sub-paragraph (1) ,

the proceedings may be continued as if they were proceedings for the recovery
of so much of the tax assessed in the self-assessment return as is due and
payable and has not been paid.

26.4

Where—

26.4.a

action is being taken under Part 1 of Schedule 8 to the F(No.2)A 2015
(enforcement of deduction from accounts) for the recovery of an amount (“ the
original amount ”) of tax assessed in a determination, and

26.4.b

before that action is concluded the determination is superseded under  sub-
paragraph (1) ,

that action may be continued as if it were an action for the recovery of so
much of the tax assessed in the return as is due and payable, has not been
paid and does not exceed the original amount.

##### Discovery assessments

27

27.1

If, in respect of an accounting period, an officer of Revenue and Customs
discovers that—

27.1.a

an amount of multinational top-up tax that ought to have been assessed in
respect of a multinational group has not been assessed, or

27.1.b

an assessment to tax is or has become insufficient,

the officer may make an assessment (a “discovery assessment”) in the amount
which ought in the officer's opinion to be charged in order to make good to
the Crown the loss of tax.

27.2

This is subject to the restrictions in  paragraph 28 .

28

28.1

This paragraph  applies where the filing member of the group has submitted a
self-assessment return under paragraph  13  for the accounting period in
respect of which the officer makes a discovery assessment.

28.2

Where  this paragraph  applies, the power to make a discovery assessment—

28.2.a

may only be made in the two cases specified in  sub-paragraphs (3)  and  (4) ,
and

28.2.b

may not be made in the circumstances specified in  sub-paragraph (6) .

28.3

The first case is where the situation mentioned in  paragraph 27 (1)  was
brought about carelessly or deliberately on the part of—

28.3.a

a member of the group of which the person forms part, or

28.3.b

a person acting on behalf of a member of the group.

28.4

The second case is where an officer of Revenue and Customs, at the time the
officer—

28.4.a

ceased to be entitled to give a notice of enquiry into the return submitted in
respect of the group for the accounting period, or

28.4.b

completed an enquiry into the return,

could not have been reasonably expected, on the basis of the information made
available to the officer before that time, to be aware of the situation
mentioned in  paragraph 27 (1) .

28.5

For this purpose information is regarded as made available to the officer of
Revenue and Customs if—

28.5.a

it is contained in a self-assessment return, an information return, an
overseas return notification or a below-threshold notification for the
accounting period in question or either of the two immediately preceding
accounting periods,

28.5.b

it is contained in any documents produced or information provided by the
filing member for the purposes of an enquiry into any such return or
notification, or

28.5.c

it is information the existence of which, and the relevance of which as
regards the situation mentioned in paragraph  27 (1) —

28.5.c.i

could reasonably be expected to be inferred by the officer of Revenue and
Customs from information falling within  paragraph (a)  or  (b) , or

28.5.c.ii

are notified in writing to an officer of Revenue and Customs by the filing
member or another person acting on the filing member's behalf.

28.6

No discovery assessment may be made if—

28.6.a

the situation mentioned in  paragraph 27 (1)  is attributable to a mistake in
the return as to the basis on which the tax liability ought to have been
calculated, and

28.6.b

the return was in fact made on the basis or in accordance with the practice
generally prevailing at the time it was made.

29

29.1

The general rule is that no discovery assessment may be made more than 4 years
after the end of the accounting period to which it relates.

29.2

A discovery assessment in a case involving a loss of tax brought about
carelessly by a member of the group (or a person acting on their behalf) may
be made at any time not more than 6 years after the end of the accounting
period to which it relates.

29.3

A discovery assessment in a case involving a loss of tax brought about
deliberately by a member of the group (or a person acting on their behalf) may
be made at any time not more than 20 years after the end of the accounting
period to which it relates.

29.4

A discovery assessment in a case involving a loss of tax brought about as a
result of a failure of a filing member to register with HMRC under  paragraph
6  may be made at any time not more than 20 years after the end of the
accounting period to which it relates.

30

30.1

The officer of Revenue and Customs must give notice of a discovery assessment
to the filing member.

30.2

The notice must state—

30.2.a

the tax due,

30.2.b

the date on which the notice is issued, and

30.2.c

the time within which any appeal against the assessment must be made.

30.3

After notice of the assessment has been served under  this paragraph , the
assessment may not be altered except as provided for by or under  this
Schedule .

30.4

Where an officer of Revenue and Customs has—

30.4.a

decided to make an assessment to tax, and

30.4.b

taken all other decisions needed for arriving at the amount of the assessment,

the officer may entrust to another officer of Revenue and Customs the
responsibility for completing the assessing procedure, whether by means
