involving the use of a computer or otherwise, including responsibility for
serving notice of the assessment.

##### Record-keeping requirements

31

31.1

The filing member of the group must—

31.1.a

keep such records as may be needed to enable it to deliver correct and
complete returns if required, and

31.1.b

preserve those records in accordance with  this paragraph .

31.2

The records must be preserved until the end of the relevant day.

31.3

“ The relevant day ” means—

31.3.a

the later of—

31.3.a.i

the ninth anniversary of the last day of the accounting period to which the
records relate, and

31.3.a.ii

if a self-assessment return relating to that accounting period is submitted
and a notice of enquiry into that return has been given before the anniversary
referred to in sub-paragraph  (i) , the day at the end of the period of six
months beginning with the day the enquiry is completed;

31.3.b

such earlier day as may be specified in a notice published by HMRC (and
different days may be specified for different cases).

31.4

The duty to preserve records may be satisfied—

31.4.a

by preserving them in any form and by any means, or

31.4.b

by preserving the information contained in them in any form and by any means,

subject to any conditions or exceptions specified in a notice published by
HMRC.

##### Payments of multinational top-up tax

###### Timing of payments

32

32.1

Multinational top-up tax due must be paid by the end of the period of 15
months beginning with the day after the end of the accounting period.

32.2

But the longer period in sub-paragraph  (3)  applies if the liability to pay
tax arises in respect of the first accounting period in relation to which a
group is a qualifying multinational group.

32.3

Where this sub-paragraph applies, multinational top-up tax due must be paid by
the end of the period of 18 months beginning with the day after the end of the
accounting period.

32.4

A person’s liability to pay multinational top-up tax may be discharged by
another member of the multinational group to which the liability relates (but
see paragraph  37 ).

###### 

33

33.1

Interest is to accrue on amounts payable under  paragraph 32 , but not paid,
from the day after the latest date on which the amounts were required to be
paid.

33.2

The rate of interest is to be as provided in regulations under section 178 of
FA 1989.

###### 

33A

33A.1

Where a person has paid an amount that has been paid by way of multinational
top-up tax but the amount is not due, the amount incurs interest at the rate
provided for in regulations made under section 178 of FA 1989 from the later
of—

33A.1.a

the day after the latest day (under paragraph 32) by which the amount paid
would have been required to be paid as multinational top-up tax if it were
due, and

33A.1.b

the day on which the amount was paid.

33A.2

See paragraph 51 for provision about making claims for the repayment of an
amount that is not tax that was due (but see also paragraph 52 which, for
example, prevents such a claim being made where an amendment to an assessment
can be, or could have been, made).

###### Group payment notices

34

34.1

An officer of Revenue and Customs may issue a group payment notice if an
amount payable by a member of a multinational group of multinational top-up
tax (including any interest on that amount) is not paid by the end of the
period of three months beginning with the relevant date.

34.2

A group payment notice may be issued to any person who is a member of the
group or who was a member of the group at   any time in the accounting period
to which the amount payable relates   (wherever in the world they are
located), subject to  paragraph 35  where the group contains ring-fenced
entities.

34.2A

The references to a member of a group in sub-paragraph (2) do not include a
member of a group that is—

34.2A.a

a securitisation company (within the meaning given by section 267(4)),

34.2A.b

a covered bond vehicle (within the meaning given by section 272A(5)), or

34.2A.c

an investment entity.

34.3

A group payment notice is a notice requiring the recipient to pay an
outstanding amount of multinational top-up tax payable by a member of the
group by a date specified in the notice.

34.4

The notice may not specify a date earlier than the date 30 days after the
notice is issued.

34.5

A group payment notice must state—

34.5.a

the amount of any tax that remains unpaid,

34.5.b

the date any tax first became payable, and

34.5.c

the member's right of appeal (see paragraph  36 (3) ).

34.6

A group payment notice may not be issued more than 3 years and 6 months after
the relevant date.

34.7

If the amount payable is as assessed in a self-assessment return, the relevant
date is the later of—

34.7.a

the date on which multinational top-up tax must be paid;

34.7.b

in a case where the return is delivered after the submission date, the date on
which the return is delivered;

34.7.c

if notice of enquiry is given, the date on which the enquiry is completed;

34.7.d

if as a result of such an enquiry the return is amended, the date of the
closure notice in relation to that enquiry;

34.7.e

if there is an appeal against the closure notice, the date on which the appeal
is finally determined.

34.8

If the amount payable is as assessed in a discovery assessment, the relevant
date is—

34.8.a

if there is no appeal against the assessment, the date on which the notice of
assessment is issued, or

34.8.b

if there is such an appeal, the date on which the appeal is finally
determined.

34.9

If the amount payable is as assessed in a determination that has not been
superseded, the relevant date is the date on which notice of the determination
was issued.

###### 

35

35.1

Where the multinational group contains ring-fenced entities, a group payment
notice may not be issued to a ring-fenced entity in respect of a liability
relating to a responsible member of the group which is not a  member of a
ring-fenced body sub-group that the entity is a member of .

35.2

A ring-fenced entity is a body corporate which is—

35.2.a

a ring-fenced body, or

35.2.b

a member of a ring-fenced body sub-group.

35.3

“ Ring-fenced body ” has the same meaning as in section 142A of the Financial
Services and Markets Act 2000.

35.4

A “ring-fenced body sub-group” is a group of entities consisting of—

35.4.a

an RFB parent undertaking and its subsidiaries, or

35.4.b

a ring-fenced body, which is not a subsidiary of an RFB parent undertaking,
and the ring-fenced body’s subsidiaries.

35.5

“ RFB parent undertaking ” means a body corporate which is subject to rules
made under section 192JA of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (rules
applying to parent undertakings of ring-fenced bodies).

###### 

36

36.1

The effect of a group payment notice being issued under  paragraph 34  is that
the recipient is treated as if—

36.1.a

a liability of a member other than the recipient were a liability of the
recipient (“the deemed liability”),

36.1.b

the deemed liability became due and payable when the relevant liability became
due and payable, and

36.1.c

any payments made in respect of the relevant liability were made in respect of
the deemed liability.

36.2

Nothing in  this paragraph  gives the recipient a right to appeal against any
assessment, determination or other decision giving rise to a liability of a
member other than the recipient (or against the deemed liability).

36.3

The recipient may appeal against the notice, within the period of 30 days
beginning with the date on which it is given, on the ground that the
recipient is not a person to whom the notice can be given (see paragraphs
34(2) and (2A) and 35(1)).

36.4

Where an appeal is made, anything required by the notice to be paid is due and
payable as if there had been no appeal.

###### Effect of group payment for tax purposes

37

37.1

This paragraph applies where a member of a multinational group (the “payer”)
makes a payment in respect of the liability to pay multinational top-up tax of
another member of the same group (the “payee”) (whether or not in consequence
of a group payment notice).

37.2

The payer may recover the amount from the payee.

37.3

In calculating the payer's income, profits or losses for tax purposes—

37.3.a

the payment is not allowed as a deduction, and

37.3.b

the reimbursement of any such payment is not to be regarded as a receipt.

37.4

The payment—

37.4.a

is not to be taken into account in calculating the profits or losses of either
the payer or payee for corporation tax or income tax purposes of either the
payer or the payee, and

37.4.b

is not to be regarded as a distribution for   income tax or  corporation tax
purposes.

37.5

The amount paid by the payer is to be taken into account in calculating—

37.5.a

the amount unpaid by the payee for tax purposes, and

37.5.b

the amount due by virtue of a group payment notice relating to the amount
unpaid.

37.6

Similarly, any payment by the   payee   of any of the amount unpaid is to be
taken into account in calculating the amount due by virtue of a group payment
notice (or by virtue of any other group payment notice relating to the amount
unpaid).

37.7

In this paragraph, “ for tax purposes ” means for the purposes of income tax,
corporation tax, multinational top-up tax or domestic top-up tax.

###### Partnership payment notices

37A

37A.1

An officer of Revenue and Customs may issue a partnership payment notice if an
amount of multinational top-up tax payable by a member of a multinational
group that is a partnership (including any interest on that amount) is not
paid by the end of the period of three months beginning with the relevant date
(see paragraph 34(7) to (9)).

37A.2

A partnership payment notice may be issued to any person (wherever in the
world they are located) who—

37A.2.a

is a partner, or

37A.2.b

was a partner at any time in the accounting period to which the amount payable
relates.

37A.3

A partnership payment notice is a notice requiring the recipient to pay an
outstanding amount of multinational top-up tax payable by a member of the
group that is a partnership by a date specified in the notice.

37A.4

Sub-paragraphs (4) to (9) of paragraph 34 and paragraph 36 apply to a
partnership payment notice as they apply to a group payment notice.

37A.5

In this paragraph and in  paragraph 37B , reference to a partner, in the case
of a limited partnership, is to a general partner.

###### Recovery of partnership payment and effect for tax purposes etc

37B

37B.1

This paragraph applies where a partner of a member of a multinational group
that is a partnership (the “payer”) makes a payment in respect of the
liability to pay multinational top-up tax of the partnership (whether or not
in consequence of a partnership payment notice).

37B.2

The payer may recover the amount from the other partners.

37B.3

In calculating the payer's income, profits or losses for tax purposes—

37B.3.a

the payment is not allowed as a deduction, and

37B.3.b

the reimbursement of any such payment is not to be regarded as a receipt.

37B.4

The payment or its reimbursement—

37B.4.a

is not (otherwise) to be taken into account in calculating the profits or
losses of for corporation tax or income tax purposes of either the payer or
the other partners, and

37B.4.b

is not to be regarded as a distribution for income tax or corporation tax
purposes.

37B.5

The amount paid by the payer is to be taken into account in calculating—

37B.5.a

the amount of multinational top-up tax unpaid by the partnership, and

37B.5.b

the amount due by virtue of a partnership payment notice relating to the
amount unpaid.

37B.6

Similarly, any payment by the partnership or by any of the other partners of
any of the amount unpaid is to be taken into account in calculating the amount
due by virtue of a partnership payment notice (or by virtue of any other
partnership payment notice relating to the amount unpaid).

37B.7

In this paragraph, “ for tax purposes ” means for the purposes of income tax,
corporation tax, multinational top-up tax or domestic top-up tax.

###### Recovery

38

38.1

Any amount due by way of multinational top-up tax liability is recoverable as
a debt due to the Crown.

38.2

“ Multinational top-up tax liability ”, in relation to a multinational group
for an accounting period, means—

38.2.a

a liability of any person who was a member of the group in the period to
multinational top-up tax in respect of the period;

38.2.b

a liability of a person to a penalty referred to in paragraph  40  for
anything done (or not done) in respect of the period.

###### Power to make regulations

39

39.1

The Treasury may by regulations make further provision about the payment of
multinational top-up tax in circumstances where—

39.1.a

a member of a group makes a payment on behalf of another member of the group,
...

39.1.aa

a partner of a partnership makes a payment on behalf of the partnership or
another partner, or

39.1.b

a member of a group is also liable to pay domestic top-up tax.

39.2

The regulations may in particular make provision for—

39.2.a

deeming a payment made by one member of a group to have been made by another;

39.2.aa

deeming a payment made by a partner of a partnership to have been made by the
partnership or another partner;

39.2.b

deeming a payment made in respect of multinational top-up tax to have been
made in respect of domestic top-up tax.

##### Penalties

###### Penalties payable in connection with 

40

This Part  of  this Schedule  sets out penalties payable in connection with
this Schedule , as follows—

40.a

paragraph  41  amends Schedule 41 to FA 2008 to impose a penalty on a filing
member of a multinational group that fails to register with or otherwise
notify HMRC under  Part 3  of  this Schedule ;

40.b

paragraph 42  imposes a penalty on a filing member of a registered group that
fails to submit an information return or overseas return notification under
Part 4  of  this Schedule ;

40.c

paragraph 43  imposes a penalty on a filing member of a registered group that
fails to submit a self-assessment return or below-threshold notification under
Part 5  of  this Schedule ;

40.d

paragraph  45  amends Schedule 24 to FA 2007 to impose a penalty on a filing
member of a multinational group that provides inaccurate information to HMRC;

40.e

paragraph 46  imposes a penalty on a filing member of a multinational group
that fails to keep or preserve records under  Part 9  of  this Schedule .

###### 

41

In paragraph 1 of Schedule 41 to FA 2008 (penalties for failure to notify
etc), in the table after the entry relating to digital services tax insert—

Multinational top-up tax Obligation of a filing member of a multinational
group under Part  3  of  Schedule 14  to FA 2023.

.

###### 

42

42.1

A penalty is payable if the filing member fails to submit an information
return or overseas return notification by the submission date, unless
paragraph 44  (reasonable excuse) applies.

42.2

The penalty is—

42.2.a

£100, if the return or notification is submitted within three months after the
submission date;

42.2.b

£200, if the return or notification is submitted within six months after the
submission date;

42.2.c

£200 plus the additional penalty amount, in any other case.

42.3

For a third successive failure, the amount referred to in—

42.3.a

sub-paragraph (2) (a)  is increased to £500;

42.3.b

sub-paragraph (2) (b)  and  (c)  is increased to £1,000.

42.4

For this purpose, a “third successive failure” occurs where—

42.4.a

the duty to submit a return or notification applies in relation to a group for
three successive accounting periods,

42.4.b

the member was liable to a penalty under  this paragraph  in respect of each
of the first two accounting periods, and

42.4.c

the member is liable to a penalty under  this paragraph  in respect of the
third accounting period.

42.5

The additional penalty amount is £60 multiplied by the number of days, after
the day six months after the submission date, on which the filing member fails
to submit the return or notification.

42.6

The submission date is the last date the filing member is permitted to submit
the return or notification under  Part 4  of this Schedule.

###### 

43

43.1

A penalty is payable if the filing member fails to submit a self-assessment
return or below-threshold notification by the submission date, unless
paragraph 44  (reasonable excuse) applies.

43.2

The penalty is—

43.2.a

£100, if the return or notification is submitted within three months after the
submission date;

43.2.b

£200, if the return or notification is submitted within six months after the
submission date;

43.2.c

the higher of £200 and 10% of the unpaid tax, if the return or notification is
submitted within twelve months after the submission date;

43.2.d

the higher of £200 and 20% of the unpaid tax, in any other case.

43.3

For a third successive failure, the amount referred to in—

43.3.a

sub-paragraph (2) (a)  is increased to £500;

43.3.b

sub-paragraph (2) (b) ,  (c)  and  (d)  is increased to £1,000.

43.4

For this purpose, a “third successive failure” occurs where—

43.4.a

the duty to submit a return or notification applies in relation to a group for
three successive accounting periods,

43.4.b

the member was liable to a penalty under  this paragraph  in respect of each
of the first two accounting periods, and

43.4.c

the member is liable to penalty under  this paragraph  in respect of the third
accounting period.

43.5

The “ unpaid tax ” means the total amount of tax payable by members of the
group for the accounting period which remains unpaid on the date when the
liability to the penalty under  this paragraph  arises.

43.6

The submission date is the last date the filing member is permitted to submit
the return or notification under  Part 5  of this Schedule.

###### 

44

44.1

This paragraph  applies if the filing member satisfies HMRC or (on appeal) the
tribunal that there is a reasonable excuse for the failure to submit the
return or notification (as the case may be).

44.2

For that purpose—

44.2.a

an insufficiency of funds is not a reasonable excuse,

44.2.b

where the member relies on any other person to do anything, that is not a
reasonable excuse unless the member took reasonable care to avoid the failure,
and

44.2.c

where the member had a reasonable excuse for the failure but the excuse has
ceased, the member is to be treated as having continued to have the excuse
only if the failure is remedied without unreasonable delay after the excuse
ceased.

###### 

45

In paragraph 1 of Schedule 24 to FA 2007 (penalties for errors etc), in the
table after the entry relating to digital services tax returns insert—

Multinational top-up tax Overseas return notification and information provided
with it Multinational top-up tax Self-assessment return and information
provided with it Multinational top-up tax Below-threshold notification and
information provided with it

.

###### 

46

46.1

A penalty is payable if—

46.1.a

the member breaches their obligations under  Part 9  of this Schedule in
relation to an accounting period, and

46.1.b

HMRC is not satisfied that any facts which HMRC reasonably requires to be
proved, and which would have been proved by the records, are proved by other
documentary evidence provided to HMRC.

46.2

The penalty is £3,000.

###### Penalties under paragraphs 

47

Paragraphs  48  and  49  apply in relation to a penalty payable under
paragraph 42 ,  43  or  46 .

###### 

48

48.1

HMRC must—

48.1.a

assess the penalty, and

48.1.b

notify the member of the assessment.

48.2

The assessment of a penalty—

48.2.a

is to be treated for procedural purposes in the same way as an assessment to
tax (except in respect of a matter expressly provided for by  this Schedule ),

48.2.b

may be enforced as if it were an assessment to tax (save that interest is not
to accrue on a penalty under paragraph  33 ), and

48.2.c

may be combined with an assessment to tax.

48.3

A supplementary assessment may be made in respect of a penalty if an earlier
assessment is based on an amount of tax due and payable that is found by HMRC
to be an underestimate or insufficient.

48.4

Sub-paragraph (5)  applies if—

48.4.a

an assessment in respect of a penalty is based on a liability to tax shown in
a self-assessment return, and

48.4.b

that liability is found by HMRC to be excessive.

48.5

HMRC may by notice amend the assessment so it is based on the correct amount.

48.6

An amendment under  sub-paragraph (5) —

48.6.a

does not affect when the penalty must be paid;

48.6.b

may be made after the last day on which the assessment in question could have
been made (under sub-paragraph  (7) ).

48.7

An assessment of a penalty must be made before the end of the period of 12
months beginning with—

48.7.a

the end of the appeal period for the assessment of the liability to tax shown
in the self-assessment return, or

48.7.b

if there is no such assessment, the date on which that liability is
ascertained or it is ascertained that the liability is nil.

48.8

In  sub-paragraph (7)  “ appeal period ” means the period during which—

48.8.a

an appeal could be brought, or

48.8.b

an appeal that has been brought has not been determined or withdrawn.

48.9

A penalty must be paid before the end of the period of 30 days beginning with
the day on which notification of the penalty is issued.

###### 

49

49.1

If HMRC thinks it right because of special circumstances, HMRC may reduce the
penalty.

49.2

In  sub-paragraph (1)  “ special circumstances ” does not include—

49.2.a

ability to pay, or

49.2.b

the fact that a potential loss of revenue from one taxpayer is balanced by a
potential over-payment by another.

49.3

In  sub-paragraph (1)  the reference to reducing a penalty includes a
reference to—

49.3.a

staying a penalty, and

49.3.b

agreeing a compromise in relation to proceedings in respect of a penalty.

###### Multiple penalties in respect of same accounting period

50

50.1

This paragraph applies where a person incurs more than one penalty in respect
of multinational top-up tax in the same accounting period.

50.2

The amount of each penalty after the first is to be reduced so that the total
amount of all such penalties in the period does not exceed the greatest amount
incurred for any such penalty.

##### Appeals and claims

###### Claims in relation to overpaid tax

51

51.1

A person (a “claimant”) who has paid an amount by way of multinational top-up
tax may make a claim to the Commissioners for repayment of tax that was not
due.

51.2

The claim must—

51.2.a

be made on or before the overpayment claim date,

51.2.b

be in the form and contain information specified in a notice published by
HMRC, and

51.2.c

not be submitted at the same time as a self-assessment return.

51.3

The overpayment claim date is the date four years after the end of the
accounting period in respect of which the amount was paid.

51.4

The Commissioners must give effect to a claim as made, unless—

51.4.a

a condition in  sub-paragraph (2)  is not met in relation to the claim,

51.4.b

paragraph 52  applies, or

51.4.c

the claim is amended following an enquiry under  paragraph 53 .

51.5

The Commissioners are not  ...  liable to repay any amount paid by way of
multinational top-up tax by reason of the fact it was not tax due  otherwise
than—

51.5.a

pursuant to a claim under this paragraph, or

51.5.b

in accordance with another provision of this Schedule.

51.6

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

51.7

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

51.8

Paragraph  54  makes further provision in relation to amounts repaid.

###### 

52

52.1

This paragraph  applies where one or more of Cases A to D apply.

52.2

Case A applies where a member of the claimant’s group has an unpaid liability
to tax.

52.3

Case B applies where the claimant is seeking or will be able to seek relief by
taking other steps under  this Part  of this Act.

52.4

Case C applies where the claimant—

52.4.a

could have sought relief by taking such steps within a period that has now
expired, and

52.4.b

knew, or ought reasonably to have known, before the end of that period that
such relief was available.

52.5

Case D applies where—

52.5.a

the amount paid is excessive by reason of a mistake in calculating the amount
of tax payable by members of the claimant’s group for the accounting period,
and

52.5.b

the amount was calculated in accordance with the practice generally prevailing
at the time.

52.6

Where  this paragraph  applies, the Commissioners are not liable to repay any
amount paid by way of multinational top-up tax by reason of the fact it was
not tax due.

###### 

53

53.1

An officer of Revenue and Customs may enquire into a claim if, within the time
allowed, the officer gives notice to the claimant of the officer's intention
to do so.

53.2

The time allowed is the period ending with the quarter day next following the
first anniversary of the day on which the claim was made.

53.3

The quarter days are 31 January, 30 April, 31 July and 31 October.

53.4

A claim enquired into under  sub-paragraph (1)  may not be the subject of a
further notice under that sub-paragraph.

53.5

An enquiry is completed when the officer by notice (a “closure notice”)
informs the claimant that the enquiry is complete and states the conclusion
reached in the enquiry.

53.6

The conclusion must be one of the following—

53.6.a

that no amendment of the claim is required, or

53.6.b

that the amendments of the claim specified in the notice are to be made.

53.7

A closure notice takes effect when it is issued.

53.8

The officer must give effect to any amendments made by the closure notice by
making such adjustments as may be necessary whether—

53.8.a

by way of assessment, or

53.8.b

by discharge or repayment of tax.

53.9

The adjustments must be made within 30 days of the date of issue of the
closure notice.

53.10

Paragraph 23  (direction to complete enquiry) applies in relation to an
enquiry under  this paragraph  as it applies in relation to an enquiry under
paragraph 16 .

###### 

54

54.1

This paragraph  applies where—

54.1.a

an amount has been paid by way of a repayment of tax, and

54.1.b

the amount paid exceeded the amount which the Commissioners were or could be
liable at that time to repay.

54.2

The Commissioners may—

54.2.a

to the best of their judgment, assess the amount of the excess, and

54.2.b

notify the amount to the person to whom the repayment was made.

54.3

Sub-paragraph (4)  applies where—

54.3.a

an assessment has been notified under  sub-paragraph (2) , and

54.3.b

it appears to the Commissioners that the amount which ought to have been
assessed as due exceeds the amount that has already been assessed.

54.4

The Commissioners may—

54.4.a

on or before the last day on which the assessment could have been made, make a
supplementary assessment of the amount of tax due, and

54.4.b

notify the amount to the person to whom the repayment was made.

54.5

An amount assessed and notified under  sub-paragraph (2)  or  (4)  counts as a
liability to multinational top-up tax for the purposes of  this Part  of this
Act.

54.6

But  sub-paragraph (5)  does not have effect if, or to the extent that, the
assessment has been withdrawn or reduced.

54.7

An assessment under  this paragraph  may not be made more than 4 years after
the end of the accounting period in which evidence of facts sufficient in the
opinion of the Commissioners to justify making the assessment comes to their
knowledge.

###### Appeals of decisions: general

55

55.1

An appeal may be brought against—

55.1.a

an amendment of a self-assessment return under  paragraph 19  (amendment
during enquiry to prevent loss of tax);

55.1.b

an amendment made by a closure notice under  paragraph 22 ;

55.1.c

a discovery assessment;

55.1.d

an assessment of a penalty under  paragraph 42 ,  43  or  46 ;

55.1.e

an amendment made by a closure notice under  paragraph 53 ;

55.1.f

an assessment made under paragraph  54 .

55.2

Any such appeal is to be brought by the filing member (“ the appellant ”).

55.3

Notice of the appeal must be given to HMRC—

55.3.a

in writing, and

55.3.b

within 30 days after the specified date.

55.4

“ Specified date ” means—

55.4.a

in relation to an appeal under  sub-paragraph (1) (a) , the date on which the
notice of amendment was issued;

55.4.b

in relation to an appeal under  sub-paragraph (1) (b)  or  (e) , the date on
which the closure notice was issued;

55.4.c

in relation to an appeal under  sub-paragraph (1) (c) ,  (d)  or  (f) , the
date on which the notice of assessment was issued.

55.5

The notice of appeal must specify the grounds of appeal.

55.6

Notice may be given after the time limit in  sub-paragraph (3) (b)  if—

55.6.a

HMRC agrees, or

55.6.b

where HMRC does not agree, the tribunal gives permission.

55.7

HMRC must agree to notice being given after the time limit if the appellant
has requested in writing that HMRC do so and HMRC is satisfied—

55.7.a

that there was a reasonable excuse for not giving the notice before the time
limit, and

55.7.b

that the request has been made without unreasonable delay.

55.8

If a request of the kind mentioned in  sub-paragraph (7)  is made, HMRC must
notify the appellant of whether or not HMRC agrees to the request.

###### 

56

56.1

The effect of a notice of appeal being given is that—

56.1.a

a review may be conducted by HMRC into the matter to which the appeal relates;

56.1.b

HMRC and the appellant may settle the appeal by agreement;

56.1.c

the appeal may be determined by the tribunal;

56.1.d

a payment of multinational top-up tax may be postponed pending determination
of the appeal.

56.2

But if—

56.2.a

the appeal is an appeal under paragraph  55 (1) (a)  against an amendment of a
self-assessment, and

56.2.b

the appeal is made while an enquiry into the return is in progress,

sub-paragraphs  (1) (a)  and  (c)  do not apply in relation to the appeal
until the enquiry is completed.

56.3

See also paragraph  67  for special provision relating to the appeal of a
penalty under  paragraph 42 ,  43  or  46 .

###### Reviews by HMRC

57

57.1

A review is to be conducted by HMRC if—

57.1.a

the appellant notifies HMRC that it requires HMRC to review the matter, or

57.1.b

HMRC offers to review the matter and the appellant accepts the offer within
the period of 30 days beginning with the date of the offer (the “acceptance
period”).

57.2

The appellant may not notify HMRC that the appellant requires HMRC to review
the matter if—

57.2.a

the appellant has already done so in relation to the same matter,

57.2.b

HMRC has offered to review the matter, or

57.2.c

the appellant has notified the appeal to the tribunal.

57.3

HMRC may not offer to review the matter if—

57.3.a

HMRC has already done so in relation to the same matter,

57.3.b

the appellant has notified HMRC that the appellant requires HMRC to review the
matter, or

57.3.c

the appellant has notified the appeal to the tribunal.

57.4

An offer by HMRC to review the matter must—

57.4.a

be made in writing, and

57.4.b

contain a statement of HMRC’s view of the matter.

57.5

If the appellant does not accept the offer within the acceptance period—

57.5.a

HMRC's view of the matter is to be treated as if it were contained in a
settlement agreement under paragraph  61 , but

57.5.b

the right to withdraw from such an agreement does not apply in relation to
that notional agreement.

57.6

Sub-paragraph (5)  does not apply to the matter if, or to the extent that, the
appellant notifies the appeal to the tribunal.

57.7

The appellant may notify the appeal to the tribunal—

57.7.a

within the acceptance period;

57.7.b

after the end of that period only if the tribunal gives permission.

###### 

58

58.1

The review is to be conducted as follows.

58.2

If the appellant required the review, HMRC must notify the appellant of HMRC’s
view of the matter within—

58.2.a

the period of 30 days beginning with the day on which HMRC received
notification of the requirement to review from the appellant, or

58.2.b

such longer period as is reasonable.

58.3

The nature and extent of the review are to be such as appear appropriate to
HMRC in the circumstances.

58.4

For the purpose of  sub-paragraph (3) , HMRC must, in particular, have regard
to steps taken before the beginning of the review—

58.4.a

by HMRC in deciding the matter, and

58.4.b

by any person in seeking to resolve disagreement about the matter.

58.5

The review must take account of any representations made by the appellant at a
stage which gives HMRC a reasonable opportunity to consider them.

###### 

59

59.1

The review may conclude that HMRC's view of the matter (as notified to the
appellant under paragraph  57 (4)  or  58 (2) ) is to be—

59.1.a

upheld,

59.1.b

varied, or

59.1.c

cancelled.

59.2

HMRC must notify the appellant of the conclusions of the review and the
reasoning for those conclusions within—

59.2.a

the period of 45 days beginning with the relevant day, or

59.2.b

such other period as may be agreed.

59.3

In  sub-paragraph (2)  “ relevant day ” means—

59.3.a

in a case where the appellant required the review, the day when HMRC notified
the appellant of HMRC's view of the matter;

59.3.b

in a case where HMRC offered the review, the day when HMRC received
notification of the appellant's acceptance of the offer.

59.4

If HMRC do not give notice of the conclusions of the review within the period
specified in  sub-paragraph (3) , the review is treated as having concluded
that HMRC's view of the matter in question is upheld.

59.5

If  sub-paragraph (4)  applies, HMRC must notify the appellant of the
conclusions which the review is treated as having reached.

59.6

The conclusions of a review are to be treated as if they were contained in a
settlement agreement under paragraph  61 , but the right to withdraw from such
an agreement does not apply in relation to that notional agreement.

59.7

Sub-paragraph (6)  does not apply to the matter if, or to the extent that, the
appellant notifies the appeal to the tribunal.

59.8

The appellant may notify the appeal to the tribunal—

59.8.a

within the post-review period;

59.8.b

after the end of that period only if the tribunal gives permission.

59.9

The post-review period is—

59.9.a

if HMRC has notified the appellant of the conclusions of the review in
accordance with  sub-paragraph (2) , the period of 30 days beginning with that
notice;

59.9.b

if HMRC has not so notified the appellant, the period beginning with the day
following the last day of the period specified in  sub-paragraph (2)  and
ending 30 days after the date on which HMRC gives notice in accordance with
sub-paragraph (5) .

###### 

60

60.1

In  paragraphs 57  to  59 , a reference to the appellant includes a person
acting on behalf of the appellant except in relation to—

60.1.a

notification by HMRC of an offer of review (and of their view of the matter)
under  paragraph 57 ;

60.1.b

notification of HMRC's view under  paragraph 58 (2) (a) ;

60.1.c

notification of the conclusions of a review under  paragraph 59 (2)  or  (5) .

60.2

But if any such notification is given to the appellant, a copy of the
notification may also be given to a person acting on behalf of the appellant.

60.3

A notification in connection with a review must be given in writing.

###### Settlement agreements

61

61.1

“ Settlement agreement ” means an agreement in writing between the appellant
and an officer of Revenue and Customs that is—

61.1.a

entered into before the appeal is determined, and

61.1.b

to the effect that the decision appealed against should be upheld without
variation, varied in a particular manner or discharged or cancelled.

61.2

Where a settlement agreement is entered into in relation to an appeal, the
consequences are to be the same (for all purposes) as if, at the time the
agreement was entered into, the tribunal had decided the appeal and had upheld
the decision without variation, varied it in that manner or discharged or
cancelled it, as the case may be.

61.3

Sub-paragraph (2)  does not apply if, within 30 days beginning with the date
on which the settlement agreement was entered into, the appellant gives notice
in writing to HMRC that it wishes to withdraw from the agreement.

61.4

Sub-paragraph (5)  applies where notice of an appeal has been given and—

61.4.a

the appellant notifies HMRC, orally or in writing, that the appellant does not
wish to proceed with the appeal, and

61.4.b

HMRC does not, within 30 days after that notification, give the appellant
notice in writing indicating that HMRC is unwilling that the appeal should be
withdrawn.

61.5

Sub-paragraphs (1)  to  (3)  have effect as if, at the date of the appellant's
notification, the appellant and an officer of Revenue and Customs had agreed
that the decision under appeal should be upheld without variation.

###### Determination by tribunal

62

62.1

The appellant may notify the appeal to the tribunal.

62.2

If the tribunal decides that a person is overcharged to multinational top-up
tax, the assessment must be reduced accordingly.

62.3

If the tribunal decides that a person is undercharged to multinational top-up
tax, the assessment must be increased accordingly.

62.4

In a case where neither  sub-paragraph (2)  or  (3)  apply, the assessment is
to stand good.

62.5

On the determination of the appeal—

62.5.a

any tax overpaid must be repaid as if a claim had been made under  paragraph
51  on the day notice of the appeal was given to HMRC;

62.5.b

any tax payable in accordance with the determination is payable in accordance
with  paragraph 32 .

62.6

Interest is to be incurred on amounts payable in accordance with those
paragraphs.

62.7

Where a party to an appeal to the tribunal makes a further appeal, tax is to
be payable or repayable in accordance with the determination of the tribunal
or court (as the case may be), even though the further appeal is pending.

62.8

But if the amount charged by the assessment is altered by the order or
judgment of the Upper Tribunal or court, then—

62.8.a

if too much tax has been paid, the amount overpaid must be refunded, with any
interest allowed by the order or judgment, and

62.8.b

if too little tax has been charged, the tax is payable in accordance with
paragraph 32 .

62.9

The determination of the tribunal is final and conclusive except as otherwise
provided in  sections 10 to 16  of the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act
2007.

###### Postponement of payment pending appeal

63

63.1

The general rule is that an appeal under  this Part  of  this Schedule  does
not postpone any liability to pay multinational top-up tax.

63.2

Accordingly, the periods within which tax is payable under  paragraph 32
continue to apply notwithstanding an appeal.

63.3

But a liability may be postponed if—

63.3.a

a determination is made by HMRC to that effect;

63.3.b

a direction is made by a tribunal to that effect;

63.3.c

HMRC and the appellant agree to a postponement.

63.4

The effect of a liability being postponed is that the period within which the
tax is payable is extended by the period of the postponement.

63.5

The period of the postponement—

63.5.a

may not begin after the date the appeal is determined;

63.5.b

is to end on the date the appeal is determined.

###### 

64

64.1

The appellant may apply to HMRC for a determination if the appellant has
grounds to believe that—

64.1.a

a person has been overcharged to multinational top-up tax;

64.1.b

an amount of tax postponed under a previous determination is excessive or
insufficient.

64.2

An application must be made within 30 days after the specified date (see
paragraph 55 (4) ), unless  sub-paragraph (3)  applies.

64.3

This sub-paragraph applies if—

64.3.a

there is a change in the circumstances of the case as a result of which the
appellant has grounds to believe the matter in  sub-paragraph (1) , or

64.3.b

the application could, if it were a notice of appeal, be given at a later date
under  paragraph 55 (6) .

64.4

The application must state the amount believed to be overcharged and the
grounds for that belief.

64.5

HMRC may determine—

64.5.a

whether any amount of tax is to be postponed, and

64.5.b

the amount of any tax postponed.

64.6

The amount of any tax postponed is to be determined as the amount (if any) by
which it appears that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the
person is overcharged.

###### 

65

65.1

The appellant may apply to the tribunal for a direction if—

65.1.a

the appellant has applied to HMRC for a determination,

65.1.b

HMRC has made a determination, and

65.1.c

the appellant does not agree with the determination.

65.2

The tribunal may direct whether the determination of HMRC was correct.

65.3

A decision of the tribunal under  this paragraph  is final and conclusive
(despite the provisions of sections 12 and 15 of the Tribunals, Courts and
Enforcement Act 2007).

###### 

66

66.1

HMRC and the appellant may agree that payment of an amount of tax should be
postponed pending the determination of the appeal.

66.2

The agreement may modify a determination by HMRC under  paragraph 64 .

66.3

Where the agreement does so, it is to be treated in the same way as a
settlement agreement under  paragraph 61 .

66.4

The consequences of an agreement are to be the same as if the tribunal had, at
the time when the agreement was entered into, made a direction to the same
effect as the agreement.

66.5

The existence of an agreement does not preclude a further determination by
HMRC or direction by the tribunal modifying the agreement.

66.6

An agreement—

66.6.a

must be made in writing;

66.6.b

may be made with a person acting on behalf of the appellant in relation to the
appeal.

###### Special provisions as to penalties

67

67.1

This paragraph  applies to an appeal as to—

67.1.a

whether a penalty under  paragraph 42 ,  43  or  46  is payable;

67.1.b

the amount of such a penalty.

67.2

Payment of the penalty is always postponed pending determination of the
appeal.

67.3

Accordingly—

67.3.a

paragraphs 63 (1)  to  (3)  and  64  to  66  do not apply to such an appeal;

67.3.b

paragraphs  63 (4)  and  (5)  always apply to such an appeal.

67.4

If the appeal is notified to the tribunal, the tribunal may—

67.4.a

confirm a decision of HMRC;

67.4.b

substitute for the decision another decision that HMRC had power to make.

67.5

The tribunal may only make a decision that HMRC had power to make under
paragraph 49  (reduction of penalties) if the tribunal considers HMRC’s
decision to have been flawed when considered in light of the principles
applicable in proceedings for judicial review.

67.6

On determination of the appeal, where a penalty is payable it is to be paid
before the end of 30 days beginning with the day on which the determination
was issued.

##### Other amendments

68

68.1

In section 1(1) of the Provisional Collection of Taxes Act 1968 (temporary
statutory effect of House of Commons resolutions affecting income tax etc)
after “digital services tax,” insert  “multinational top-up tax,” .

68.2

In section 178(2) of FA 1989 (setting of interest rates), at the end insert—

68.2.x

paragraphs  33  and  51  of  Schedule 14  to the Finance Act 2023.

.

68.3

In paragraph 63(1) of Schedule 36 to FA 2008 (information and inspection
powers), after paragraph (cc) insert—

68.3.cd

multinational top-up tax;

.

68.4

In section 206(3) of FA 2013, at the end insert—

68.4.h

multinational top-up tax.

.

                 Multinational top-up tax: elections

Section 127(9)

##### Long term elections

1

1.1

This paragraph  applies to an election under the following provisions of Part
3—

1.1.a

section 127 (8) ;

1.1.aa

section 141(7);

1.1.b

section 161 ;

1.1.c

section 162 ;

1.1.d

section 164 ;

1.1.e

section 165 ;

1.1.f

section 166 ;

1.1.g

section 187 ;

1.1.h

section 213 ;

1.1.i

section 214 .

1.2

An election to which  this paragraph  applies—

1.2.a

must specify the first accounting period for which it is to have effect (“the
first election period”),

1.2.b

must be made no later than the date by which the information return or
overseas return notification in respect of that period is due,

1.2.c

must be included in an information return submitted to HMRC or a qualifying
authority in respect of that period, and

1.2.d

has effect for the first election period and each subsequent accounting period
until the commencement of the first accounting period for which a revocation
of the election has effect.

1.3

A revocation of an election to which  this paragraph  applies is to be made by
the filing member of a multinational group and—

1.3.a

must specify the first accounting period for which it is to have effect,

1.3.b

must be made no later than the date by which the information return or
overseas return notification in respect of that period is due, and

1.3.c

must be included in an information return submitted to HMRC or a qualifying
authority in respect of that period.

1.4

But a revocation of an election to which  this paragraph  applies may not be
made that has effect for the first election period or any of the next 4
accounting periods.

1.5

Where an election to which  this paragraph  applies has been revoked, no
further election of the same type may be made that has effect for the first
accounting period for which the revocation has effect or any of the next 4
accounting periods.

##### Annual elections

2

2.1

This paragraph  applies to an election under the following provisions of Part
3—

2.1.za

section 176D(3)(b);

2.1.a

section 186 ;

2.1.b

section 163 ;

2.1.c

section 182 (8) ;

2.1.d

section 189 ;

2.1.e

section 195 (2) ;

2.1.ea

section 199;

2.1.f

section 205 ;

2.1.fa

section 216;

2.1.g

section 217 (8) ;

2.1.h

section 221 (4) ;

2.1.i

paragraph 2 (9)  of  Schedule 16 ;

2.1.j

paragraph 3  of  Schedule 16 ;

2.1.k

paragraph 14 of Schedule 16;

2.1.l

paragraph 1 of Schedule 16A.

2.2

An election to which  this paragraph  applies—

2.2.a

must specify the accounting period for which it is to have effect,

2.2.b

must be made no later than the date by which the information return or
overseas return notification in respect of that period is due, and

2.2.c

must be included in an information return submitted to HMRC or a qualifying
authority in respect of that period.

Multinational top-up tax: transitional provision

Section 260

##### General transitional measures

###### Transitional relief for substance-based income exclusion

1

1.1

Section 195 (4)  (payroll carve-out amount) has effect for an accounting
period that commences in a year listed in following table as if for “5%” there
were substituted the specified percentage for that year—

Year Specified percentage 2023 10% 2024 9.8% 2025 9.6% 2026 9.4% 2027 9.2%
2028 9.0% 2029 8.2% 2030 7.4% 2031 6.6% 2032 5.8%

1.2

Section 195 (5)  (tangible asset carve-out amount) has effect for an
accounting period that commences in a year listed in following table as if for
“5%” there were substituted the specified percentage for that year—

Year Specified percentage 2023 8% 2024 7.8% 2025 7.6% 2026 7.4% 2027 7.2% 2028
7.0% 2029 6.6% 2030 6.2% 2031 5.8% 2032 5.4%

###### Intra-group transfers before entry into regime

2

2.1

Sub-paragraph (3)  applies where—

2.1.a

assets are transferred from one member of a multinational group to another
member of that group,

2.1.b

the Pillar Two rules do not apply to the transferor for the accounting period
in which the transfer takes place (but in determining this, section 255(4) has
effect as if sub-paragraph (ii) of paragraph (b) were omitted),

2.1.ba

a qualifying domestic top-up tax does not apply in relation to the transferor
for that period, and

2.1.c

the transfer took place on or after 1 December 2021.

2.2

But  sub-paragraph (3)  does not apply in relation to a transfer of assets
manufactured, or of a class or description sold, in the course of carrying on
a trade by the transferor or the transferee.

2.3

Where this sub-paragraph applies, for the purposes of  Part 3  of this Act—

2.3.a

the value of the assets at the relevant time is the carrying value of the
assets in the hands of the transferor immediately before the transfer, and

2.3.b

any deferred tax asset that would arise in relation to the assets in the
underlying profits of the transferee is limited to   the lesser of the cap
amount and the sum of—

2.3.b.i

the value of deferred tax assets that arose in relation to the assets before
their transfer, and

2.3.b.ii

the tax paid amount in relation to the transfer of assets.

2.3A

For the purposes of determining the value of a deferred tax asset under sub-
paragraph (3)(b)(i)—

2.3A.a

if the rate of tax in relation to that asset is greater than 15%, the value is
to be adjusted so that it reflects the value it would be if the rate had been
15%, and

2.3A.b

exclude the impact of any valuation adjustments or accounting recognition
adjustments.

2.4

For the purposes of this paragraph “ the relevant time ” means the later of—

2.4.a

the date of the transfer, and

2.4.b

the commencement of the first accounting period in which  the Pillar Two rules
apply to the transferee.

2.4.b.i

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

2.4.b.ii

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

2.5

Where the relevant time is after the date of the transfer—

2.5.a

the value of the assets at the relevant time is to be adjusted to reflect—

2.5.a.i

capitalised expenditure incurred in respect of the assets in the period
between the date of the transfer and the relevant time, and

2.5.a.ii

amortisation and depreciation of the assets that, had the transfer not
occurred, would have been recognised by the transferor if the transferor had
continued to use the accounting policies and rates for amortisation and
depreciation of the assets previously used, and

2.5.b

the tax paid amount in relation to the transfer of the assets   , and the
value of deferred tax assets that arose in relation to the assets before their
transfer, are   to be adjusted to reflect the matters referred to in
paragraph (a) (i)  and  (ii) .

2.6

To determine the “ tax paid amount ” in relation to a transfer of assets take
the following steps—

Step 1 Determine the amount of the tax expense of the transferor in relation
to the transfer of the assets that relates to covered taxes. Step 2 Determine
the amount, if any, of qualifying current tax expense relating to the transfer
of the assets that would have been allocated to the transferor as a result of
section 177  or  179  (permanent establishments and controlled foreign company
regimes) if—   the ultimate parent had been located in the United Kingdom and
the accounting period commenced on or after 31 December 2023, and   section
179 (2)  (restriction of allocation of mobile income) were ignored. Step 3 Add
together the amounts determined under Steps 1 and 2.

2.7

In determining the tax expense of the transferor in relation to the transfer
of the assets—

2.7.a

where any loss arising in the accounting period in which the transfer took
place is offset against any taxable gain arising on the transfer, ignore that
offsetting, and

2.7.b

exclude the impact of any valuation adjustments or accounting recognition
adjustments.

2.8

The “ cap amount ” in relation to a transfer of assets is the amount given by—

2.8.a

dividing—

2.8.a.i

the amount of tax expense determined under Step 1 in  sub-paragraph (6) , by

2.8.a.ii

the nominal rate of tax to which that expense relates, and

2.8.b

multiplying the result of  paragraph (a)  by 15%.

2.9

Where  the sum of   the tax paid amount   and the value of deferred tax assets
that arose in relation to the assets before their transfer is greater than
the cap amount  ..., the filing member may elect that  sub-paragraph (3)  does
not apply in relation to the transfer of assets.

2.10

Paragraph 2  of  Schedule 15  (annual elections) applies to an election under
sub-paragraph (9) .

2.11

For the purposes of  this paragraph ,

2.11.a

“ a transfer of assets ” includes a transaction that relates to assets that
does not result in a change in their ownership if the transaction has   a
similar effect for accounting purposes to   a change in ownership of those
assets;

2.11.b

a qualifying domestic top-up tax is not to be taken as applying to a member of
a multinational group if provision for a QDMTT Safe Harbour (within the
meaning of the Pillar Two rules) applies to it.

2.12

Where assets are transferred from one member of a multinational group to
another member of that group as a result of a series of transfers that—

2.12.a

fall within sub-paragraph (1), but

2.12.b

do not fall within sub-paragraph (2),

that series is to be treated as a single transfer of assets that falls within
sub-paragraph (1).

2.13

This paragraph applies to that single transfer as if—

2.13.a

the reference to the transferor in sub-paragraph (3)(a) were to the transferor
in relation to the first transfer in the series,

2.13.b

the references in sub-paragraph (3)(b) to the cap amount, the value of
deferred tax assets that arose in relation to the assets before their transfer
and the tax paid amount were to the aggregate of each such amount or value as
determined for the purpose of each transfer that makes up the series,

2.13.c

the reference to the date of the transfer in sub-paragraph (4)(a) were to the
date of the last transfer in the series, and

2.13.d

the references to the transferee in sub-paragraph (4)(b) were to the
transferee in relation to the last transfer in the series.

##### Transitional safe harbour

###### Transitional safe harbour election

####### Election

3

3.1

The filing member of a multinational group may make a transitional safe
harbour election for an accounting period in respect of a territory.

3.1A

The effect of the election is that all of the standard members of the group
located in the territory are to be treated as not having top-up amounts or
additional top-up amounts for the purpose of determining the liability of any
member of the group to multinational top-up tax.

3.2

An election may only be made for an accounting period if—

3.2.a

the period commences on or before 31 December 2026 and ends on or before 30
June 2028,

3.2.b

a qualifying country-by-country report has been prepared in relation to the
territory for the period,

3.2.c

the election has been made in respect of the territory for each preceding
accounting period—

3.2.c.i

that commenced on or after 31 December 2023, and

3.2.c.ii

in which the Pillar Two rules   would, ignoring any transitional safe harbour
election, have applied to any member   of the group in the territory,

3.2.d

an election under  section 189  (deemed distribution tax election) has not
been made in respect of the territory for the accounting period, and

3.2.e

at least one of the following tests are met for the territory in accounting
period—

3.2.e.i

the threshold test (see  paragraph 7 ),

3.2.e.ii

the simplified effective tax rate test (see  paragraph 8 ), or

3.2.e.iii

the routine profits test (see  paragraph 9 ).

3.3

An election may not be made in respect of the territory of the ultimate parent
of a multinational group for an accounting period if the ultimate parent is a
flow-through entity unless, were the adjusted profits of the ultimate parent
determined for that period in accordance with  Part 3 —

3.3.a

its adjusted profits would be nil as a result of the application of  section
170  (adjustments for ultimate parent that is a flow-through entity), or

3.3.b

all of the ultimate parent’s adjusted profits would be attributable to one or
more permanent establishments (see  section 159 ) and no amount of income or
expense of any permanent establishment would be treated, as a result of
section 160  (attribution of losses between permanent establishment and main
entity), as income or expense of the ultimate parent.

3.4

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

3.5

Paragraph 2  of  Schedule 15  (annual elections) applies to an election under
this paragraph .

3.6

The information return in which the election is made must set out which of the
tests referred to in  sub-paragraph (2) (e)  are being relied on and include
evidence of how any that is relied on is met.

3.7

For the purposes of this Part of this Schedule, a country-by-country report in
relation to a territory is “qualifying” if the information relating to the
territory is prepared on the basis of qualified financial statements of the
multinational group (see paragraph 4).

3.8

Where there is no requirement under the law of any territory for a country-by-
country report to be prepared and filed in respect of a multinational group,
the filling member may include, in the information return in which the
election is made, the information that would have been in such a report—

3.8.a

prepared in accordance with legislation implementing the OECD’s guidance on
country-by-country reporting under the law of the territory of the ultimate
parent, or

3.8.b

where there is no such legislation, prepared in accordance with that guidance.

3.9

Where such information has been included in that information return, that
information is to be treated as if it were a country-by-country report in
relation to the territory for the purposes of this Chapter (and where that
information complies with sub-paragraph (7), the condition in sub-paragraph
(2)(b) is to be treated as met).

####### Qualified financial statements and basis of calculations

4

4.1

For the purposes of  this Part  of  this Schedule  “qualified financial
statements” of a multinational group means—

4.1.a

the accounts used to prepare the consolidated financial statement of the
ultimate parent, or

4.1.b

financial statements of members of the group prepared in accordance with
acceptable accounting standards or an authorised accounting standard.

4.2

Where a member of a multinational group is not included in consolidated
financial statements of any member of the group on a line-by-line basis solely
due to size or materiality grounds, the financial accounts of that member that
are used for preparation of the group’s country-by-country report are to be
regarded as forming part of the qualified financial statements of the group.

4.3

For the purposes of establishing whether the tests in  paragraphs 7  to  9
are met in relation to members of a multinational group in a territory, the
basis for that determination is to be the information derived from qualified
financial statements as to—

4.3.a

revenue,

4.3.b

profit (loss) before income tax,  ...

4.3.c

qualifying income tax expense (see  paragraph 5 )  , and

4.3.d

qualified substance based income amount (see paragraph 9(2)).

4.4

Information derived from qualified financial statements as to revenue or
profit (loss) before income tax must be adjusted—

4.4.a

as the information was adjusted for the purposes of its inclusion in a
qualifying country-by-country report in relation to the territory, or

4.4.b

if the information was not included in such a report, as it would have been
adjusted had it been included in such a report.

See also  paragraph 6  which provides for circumstances in which further
adjustments are required to profit (loss) before income tax and circumstances
in which adjustments are required to qualifying income tax expense.

4.5

The information described in  sub-paragraph (3) (a)  to   (d)    that must be
used to determine whether the tests in  paragraphs 7  to  9  are met in
relation to members of a multinational group in a territory must be derived
from whichever of the following was used to prepare the qualifying country-by-
country report in relation to the territory—

4.5.a

qualified financial statements falling within  sub-paragraph (1) (a) , along
with any financial accounts treated as qualified financial statements as a
result of  sub-paragraph (2) , or

4.5.b

qualified financial statements falling within  sub-paragraph (1) (b) , along
with any financial accounts treated as qualified financial statements as a
result of  sub-paragraph (2) .

4.6

Where that information in respect of a territory is not available in qualified
financial statements of a multinational group, no election may be made in
respect of that territory.

####### Qualifying income tax expense

5

In  this Part  of  this Schedule , “ qualifying income tax expense ” means
income tax expense adjusted to exclude—

5.a

any amount that does not relate to covered taxes, and

5.b

any amount that relates to an uncertain tax position.

####### Adjustments

6

6.1

Sub-paragraph (2)  applies where the adjusted profits of the ultimate parent
of a multinational group for an accounting period would be reduced as a result
of  section 171 (1)  (ultimate parent subject to deductible dividend regime).

6.2

Where this sub-paragraph applies the profit (loss) before income tax of the
ultimate parent for that period is to be reduced (but not below nil) by the
amount referred to in  section 171 (1) .

6.3

Sub-paragraph (4)  applies where—

6.3.a

the standard members of a multinational group in a territory have a net
unrealised fair value loss for an accounting period, and

6.3.b

that loss exceeds 50 million euros.

6.4

Where this sub-paragraph applies, those losses are to be excluded from the
aggregate profit (loss) before income tax of those members.

6.5

For the purposes of  sub-paragraph (3) , the standard members of a
multinational group in a territory have a net unrealised fair value loss for
an accounting period to the extent their losses that arise from changes in
fair value of relevant ownership interests exceed gains arising from changes
in fair value of relevant ownership interests.

6.6

An ownership interest in an entity is relevant   unless , at the end of the
accounting period, the members of the multinational group do not between them
have ownership interests that entitle them to 10% or more of the entity’s —

6.6.a

profits,

6.6.b

capital,

6.6.c

reserves, and

6.6.d

voting rights.

6.7

Amounts of profits and qualifying tax expense allocated, for the purposes of
Part 3 , to a member of a multinational group from an investment entity as a
result of an election under  section 213  (investment entity tax transparency
election) are to be reflected (to the extent they are not already) in the
member’s profit (loss) before income tax and qualifying tax expense used for
the purposes of applying the tests in  paragraphs 7  to  9 .

6.8

Amounts that are to be included or otherwise taken account of, for the
purposes of  Part 3 , in the adjusted profits and covered tax balance of a
member of a multinational group as a result of an election under  section 214
(taxable distribution method election) are to be reflected (to the extent they
are not already) in the member’s profit (loss) before income tax and
qualifying tax expense used for the purposes of applying the tests in
paragraphs 7  to  9 .

####### Threshold test

7

7.1

The threshold test is met for a territory in an accounting period if—

7.1.a

the revenue of the standard members in that territory for the period is less
than 10 million euros, and

7.1.b

the aggregate profit (loss) before income tax of those members for that period
is less than 1 million euros.

7.2

Where those members include members that are held for sale and the revenue of
those members is not otherwise included in the amount determined for the
purposes of  sub-paragraph (1) (a) , that revenue is to be so included.

####### Simplified effective tax rate test

8

8.1

The simplified effective tax rate test is met for a territory in an accounting
period if the simplified effective tax rate of the standard members of the
group in that territory is—

8.1.a

in the case of an accounting period beginning before 1 January 2025, at least
15%,

8.1.b

in the case of an accounting period beginning in 2025, at least 16%, or

8.1.c

in the case of an accounting period beginning on or after 1 January 2026, at
least 17%.

8.2

The simplified effective tax rate of the standard members of a multinational
group in a territory in an accounting period is the amount (expressed as a
percentage) given by dividing—

8.2.a

the aggregate qualifying income tax expense of those members for that period,
by

8.2.b

the aggregate profit (loss) before income tax of those members for that
period.

####### Routine profits test

9

9.1

The routine profits test is met for a territory in an accounting period if—

9.1.a

the qualified substance based income exclusion amount for that territory for
that period is equal to or greater than the aggregate profit (loss) before
income tax for that period of the standard members of the group located in
that territory, or

9.1.b

the aggregate profit (loss) before income tax of those members for that period
is nil or reflects an overall loss.

9.2

The “qualified substance based income exclusion amount” for a territory for an
accounting period is the substance based exclusion determined for the
territory for the period in accordance with  section 195  (and see also
paragraph 1  of  this Schedule ) ignoring any payroll carve-out amount or
tangible asset carve-out amount of any standard member of the group in that
territory—

9.2.a

that is not regarded as a constituent entity of the multinational group for
the purposes of the group’s country-by-country report, or

9.2.b

that is not regarded as located in the territory for the purposes of that
report.

###### Application to joint ventures etc

####### Application in the case of joint venture group

10

10. 

For the purpose of applying  Chapter 1  of  this Part  of  this Schedule  to a
joint venture group (see   section 227   which applies  this Schedule
generally, with modifications, to joint venture groups)  , that Chapter has
effect as if —

10. .a

paragraph   3(2)(b)   were omitted (requirement for qualifying country-by-
country report),

10. .b

the reference in  paragraph 4 (2)  to “the financial accounts of that member
that are used for preparation of the group’s country-by-country report” were
to the financial accounts that would be used if a qualifying country-by-
country report had been prepared in respect of the joint venture group, and

10. .c

in  paragraph 9 (2) , the words from “ignoring” to the end were omitted.

10.2

For that purpose ignore section 227(1)(a) (reference to ultimate parent
treated as reference to joint venture parent).

10.3

Accordingly, the filing member of a multinational group may make a separate
transitional safe harbour election in respect of joint venture members of a
joint venture group in a territory.

####### Application to investment entities in same territory as owners

11

11.1

Subsection (2) applies where—

11.1.a

an investment entity that is a member of a multinational group, and

11.1.b

all of the members of a multinational group with direct ownership interests in
it,

are located in the same territory.

11.2

The investment entity is to be treated as a standard member of that group for
the purposes of  this Part  of  this Schedule .

####### Minority owned members

12

For the purposes of  this Part  of  this Schedule , references to the standard
members of a multinational group include minority owned members.

##### Transitional reporting election

###### Transitional reporting election

13

13.1

HMRC may publish a notice that provides for alternative requirements for the
information that must be contained in an information return in respect of
members of a multinational group to which an election under sub-paragraph (3)
applies.

13.2

Where—

13.2.a

HMRC have published a notice under paragraph (1) containing alternative
requirements, and

13.2.b

an election under sub-paragraph (3) applies to members of a multinational
group for an accounting period,

paragraph 10 of Schedule 14 applies to the filing member of the group for that
period subject to the notice.

13.3

An election under this sub-paragraph—

13.3.a

is to be made in respect of all of the members of a multinational group in a
territory,

13.3.b

is to be made by the filing member of the group,

13.3.c

may only have effect in relation to an accounting period that begins on or
before 31 December 2028 and ends before 1 July 2030, and

13.3.d

may only be made if condition A, B or C is met.

13.4

Condition A is that none of the members in the territory have top-up amounts
or additional top-up amounts for the accounting period to which the election
is to apply.

13.5

Condition B is that—

13.5.a

there is only one responsible member responsible for all of the members in the
territory for the accounting period to which the election is to apply, and

13.5.b

the sum of amounts attributed under Chapter 7 of Part 3 to that responsible
member for that period in respect of those members’ top-up amounts and
additional top-up amounts is equal to the sum of the members’ top-up amount
and additional top-up amounts.

13.6

Condition C is that—

13.6.a

there is more than one responsible member responsible for the members of the
group in the territory for the accounting period to which the election is to
apply, and

13.6.b

each responsible member is responsible for every member of the group in the
territory and has the same inclusion ratio for each member it is responsible
for.

13.7

Paragraph 2 of Schedule 15 (annual elections) applies to an election under
this paragraph.

Multinational top-up tax: safe harbours

Section 260

##### Qualifying domestic top-up tax safe harbour

###### Qualifying domestic top-up tax safe harbour election

####### Election for qualifying domestic top-up tax safe harbour

1

1.1

The filing member of a multinational group may make a qualifying domestic top-
up tax safe harbour election for an accounting period in respect of a
territory.

1.2

The effect of the election is that all of the standard members of the group
located in the territory are to be treated as not having top-up amounts or
additional top-up amounts for the purpose of determining the liability of any
member of the group to multinational top-up tax.

1.3

An election may only be made for an accounting period if—

1.3.a

a qualifying domestic top-up tax applies in that territory for that period,

1.3.b

that tax is accredited for the purposes of the election (see paragraph 2), and

1.3.c

none of the disqualifying conditions in paragraph 3 apply for that period.

1.4

Paragraph 2 of Schedule 15 (annual elections) applies to an election under
this paragraph.

####### Accredited qualifying domestic top-up tax

2

A qualifying domestic top-up tax is accredited for the purposes of an election
under paragraph 1 if that tax is specified as such in regulations made by the
Treasury.

####### Disqualifying conditions

3

3.1

Conditions A to D are disqualifying conditions for the purposes of paragraph
1(3)(c) in relation to a multinational group and a territory.

3.2

Condition A is that—

3.2.a

the ultimate parent is located in the territory,

3.2.b

the ultimate parent is a flow-through entity, and

3.2.c

the qualifying domestic top-up tax applying in the territory—

3.2.c.i

does not generally impose a charge on the ultimate parent as a result of it
being a flow-through entity, and

3.2.c.ii

does not include provision for a charge to be imposed on the ultimate parent
in circumstances where there would otherwise be an amount of tax that was not
charged to any member of the group in that territory.

3.3

Condition B is that—

3.3.a

a responsible member of the group is located in the territory,

3.3.b

the member is not the ultimate parent of the group,

3.3.c

the member is a flow-through entity, and

3.3.d

the qualifying domestic top-up tax applying in the territory—

3.3.d.i

does not generally impose a charge on the member as a result of it being a
flow-through entity, and

3.3.d.ii

does not include provision for a charge to be imposed on the member in
circumstances where there would otherwise be an amount of tax that was not
charged to any member of the group in that territory.

3.4

Condition C is that—

3.4.a

the qualifying domestic top-up tax applying in the territory provides that it
does not apply to a multinational group in the initial phase of the group’s
international expansion,

3.4.b

that provision is not limited in application to circumstances where the
members of a multinational group in the territory are not subject to Pillar
Two rules, and

3.4.c

that provision applies to the group.

3.5

Condition D is that the enforceability of an amount of qualifying domestic
top-up tax accruing to a standard member of the group is in question.

3.6

Subsections (3), (4) and (6) of section 256A (qualifying domestic top-up tax
treated as not accruing where contested) apply for the purpose of determining
whether the enforceability of an amount of qualifying domestic top-up tax is
in question.

###### Application to non-standard members of a multinational group

####### Application in the case of joint venture group

4

4.1

For the purpose of applying Chapter 1 of this Part of this Schedule to a joint
venture group (see section 227 which applies this Schedule generally, with
modifications, to joint venture groups), that Chapter has effect as if in
paragraph 3—

4.1.a

in sub-paragraph (1), for “Conditions A to D” there were substituted
“Conditions A to E” ,

4.1.b

after sub-paragraph (6), there were inserted—

4.1.b.7

Condition E is that the qualifying domestic top-up tax applying in the
territory—

4.1.b.7.a

does not generally impose a charge on members of the group that are members of
a joint venture group, and

4.1.b.7.b

does not include provision for a charge to be imposed on such members in
circumstances where there would otherwise be an amount of tax that was not
charged to any member of the group in that territory.

4.2

For that purpose ignore section 227(1)(a) (reference to ultimate parent
treated as reference to joint venture parent).

4.3

Accordingly, the filing member of a multinational group may make a separate
qualifying domestic top-up tax safe harbour election in respect of joint
venture members of a joint venture group in a territory.

####### Application in the case of investment entities

5

5.1

Chapter 1 of this Part of this Schedule to applies to investment entities and
has effect for that purpose as if—

5.1.a

references to standard members of a multinational group were to members of the
group that are investment entities, and

5.1.b

in paragraph 3—

5.1.b.i

in sub-paragraph (1), for “Conditions A to D” there were substituted
“Conditions A to E” ,

5.1.b.ii

after sub-paragraph (6), there were inserted—

5.1.b.ii.7

Condition E is that the qualifying domestic top-up tax applying in the
territory—

5.1.b.ii.7.a

does not generally impose a charge on members of the group that are investment
entities, and

5.1.b.ii.7.b

does not include provision for a charge to be imposed on such members in
circumstances where there would otherwise be an amount of tax that was not
charged to any member of the group in that territory.

5.2

Accordingly, the filing member of a multinational group may make a separate
qualifying domestic top-up tax safe harbour election in respect of members of
the group that are investment entities.

####### Application in the case of minority owned members

6

6.1

Chapter 1 of this Part of this Schedule to applies to minority owned members
of a multinational group and has effect for that purpose as if references to
standard members of a multinational group were to members of the group that
are minority owned members.

6.2

Accordingly, the filing member of a multinational group may make a separate
qualifying domestic top-up tax safe harbour election in respect of minority
owned members of the group.

section 259

                 Administration of domestic top-up tax

Section 275

##### Introduction

1

1.1

The Commissioners for His Majesty’s Revenue and Customs are responsible for
the collection and management of domestic top-up tax.

1.2

This Schedule applies (with modifications)  Schedule 14  (administration of
multinational top-up tax) for the purposes of administering domestic top-up
tax.

##### Meaning of “filing member”

2

Part  2  of  Schedule 14  applies, save that—

2.a

where a qualifying entity is not part of a group, Part  2  of  Schedule 14
does not apply, and references to “filing member” in  Schedule 14  apply as if
they were references to the qualifying entity;

2.b

where a qualifying entity is part of a group—

2.b.i

references to a “multinational group” apply as if they were references to a
group;

2.b.ii

the reference in paragraph  2 (4) (a)  of  Schedule 14  to this Schedule
applies as if it were a reference to  Schedule 14 .

##### Registration

3

Part  3  of  Schedule 14  applies as if—

3.a

for paragraph  6 (1)  and  (2)  there were substituted—

3.a.1

A filing member must register with HMRC if the filing member or, if the filing
member is a member of a group, a member of that group—

3.a.1.a

is located in the United Kingdom and

3.a.1.b

is a qualifying entity.

3.a.2

For the purposes of sub-paragraph  (1) , a qualifying entity becomes a
qualifying entity on the first day of the first accounting period it is a
qualifying entity (the  “trigger day” ).

;

3.b

references to a “multinational group” were references to a group.

##### Other administrative provisions

4

4.1

Subject to paragraph  5 , Parts  4  to  12  of  Schedule 14  apply as if—

4.1.a

references to “multinational top-up tax” were to domestic top-up tax;

4.1.b

references to “domestic top-up tax” were to multinational top-up tax;

4.1.c

references to a “multinational group” were references to a group;

4.1.d

where an entity registered under Part  3  of that Schedule (or which should
have been registered) is not part of a group—

4.1.d.i

references to a group or its members (however framed) were references to the
entity or an entity (as the context requires);

4.1.d.ii

references to “the filing member of a group” were references to the entity.

4.2

In particular, the Treasury’s power to make regulations under paragraph  39
applies in relation to payments of domestic top-up tax.

5

5.1

In Part  11  of  Schedule 14  (penalties), only paragraphs  40 (b) ,  (c)  and
(e) ,  42  to  44 , and  46  to  50  apply.

5.2

The reference in paragraph  38  of  Schedule 14  (as applied by paragraph  4 )
to a penalty referred to in paragraph  40  of that Schedule applies as if,
instead of referring to the penalties referred to in paragraph  40 (a) ,  (b)
and  (d)  of that Schedule, it referred to the penalties inserted by paragraph
6 .
